   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Greece</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Greece_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Greece (disambiguation)">Greece (disambiguation)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hellas_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Hellas (disambiguation)">Hellas</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in Southeast Europe
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p>

             <li><span style="font-size:85%;"><i lang="el-Latn" title="Greek-language romanization">Ellinikí Dimokratía</i></span></li>
            </ul>
           </div>

      <p><b>Greece</b> (<a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">Ελλάδα</span>, <i lang="el-Latn" title="Greek-language text">Elláda</i>, <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[eˈlaða]</a></span>), officially the <b>Hellenic Republic</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-:1_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-13">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[b]</a></sup> is a country located in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast Europe</a>. Its population is approximately 10.7 million as of 2018; <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a> is its largest and capital city, followed by <a href="/wiki/Thessaloniki" title="Thessaloniki">Thessaloniki</a>. Situated on the southern tip of the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, Greece is located at the crossroads of Europe, Asia, and Africa. It shares land borders with <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a> to the northwest, <a href="/wiki/North_Macedonia" title="North Macedonia">North Macedonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> to the north, and <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> to the northeast. The <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean Sea</a> lies to the east of the <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Greece" title="Geography of Greece">mainland</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Sea" title="Ionian Sea">Ionian Sea</a> to the west, the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Crete" title="Sea of Crete">Cretan Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the south. Greece has the longest coastline on the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean Basin</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_length_of_coastline" title="List of countries by length of coastline">11th longest coastline in the world</a> at 13,676&nbsp;km (8,498&nbsp;mi) in length, featuring many <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Greece" title="List of islands of Greece">islands</a>, of which 227 are inhabited. Eighty percent of Greece is mountainous, with <a href="/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Mount Olympus</a> being the highest peak at 2,918 metres (9,573&nbsp;ft). The country consists of nine <a href="/wiki/Geographic_regions_of_Greece" title="Geographic regions of Greece">traditional geographic regions</a>: <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(Greece)" title="Macedonia (Greece)">Macedonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Greece" title="Central Greece">Central Greece</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Peloponnese" title="Peloponnese">Peloponnese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thessaly" title="Thessaly">Thessaly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epirus_(region)" title="Epirus (region)">Epirus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Islands" title="Aegean Islands">Aegean Islands</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Dodecanese" title="Dodecanese">Dodecanese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cyclades" title="Cyclades">Cyclades</a>), <a href="/wiki/Western_Thrace" title="Western Thrace">Thrace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crete" title="Crete">Crete</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Islands" title="Ionian Islands">Ionian Islands</a>. </p>
      <p>Greece is considered the cradle of <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western civilization</a>, being the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Athenian_democracy" title="Athenian democracy">democracy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_philosophy" title="Western philosophy">Western philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_literature" title="Western literature">Western literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">historiography</a>, <a href="/wiki/Political_science" title="Political science">political science</a>, major <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_in_classical_antiquity" title="History of science in classical antiquity">scientific</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_mathematics" title="Greek mathematics">mathematical</a> principles, <a href="/wiki/History_of_theatre" title="History of theatre">theatre</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>. From the eighth century BC, the Greeks were organised into various independent city-states, known as <i>poleis</i> (singular <i><a href="/wiki/Polis" title="Polis">polis</a></i>), which spanned the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a>. <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Macedon" title="Philip II of Macedon">Philip II of Macedon</a> united most of present-day Greece in the fourth century BC, with his son <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> rapidly conquering much of the ancient world, from the eastern Mediterranean to India. The subsequent <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic period</a> saw the height of <a href="/wiki/Greek_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek culture">Greek culture</a> and influence in antiquity. Greece was annexed by <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Rome</a> in the second century BC, becoming an integral part of the Roman Empire and its continuation, the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, which was predominately culturally and linguistically Greek. The <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">Greek Orthodox Church</a>, which emerged in the first century AD, helped shape modern Greek identity and transmitted Greek traditions to the wider <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox world</a>. After falling under <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> dominion in the mid-15th century, Greece emerged as a modern <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> in 1830 following a <a href="/wiki/Greek_War_of_Independence" title="Greek War of Independence">war of independence</a>. The country's rich historical legacy is reflected in part by its 18 <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Greece" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Greece">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>. </p>
      <p>Greece is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_parliamentary_republic" title="Unitary parliamentary republic">unitary parliamentary republic</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a>, with an advanced <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy" title="World Bank high-income economy">high-income economy</a>, and a high <a href="/wiki/Quality_of_life" title="Quality of life">quality of life</a>, ranking simultaneously very high in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. Its economy is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_in_Europe_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of sovereign states in Europe by GDP (nominal)">largest</a> in the Balkans, where it is an important regional investor. A founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, Greece was the tenth member to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> (precursor to the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>) and has been part of the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> since 2001. It is also a member of numerous other international institutions, including the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a> (NATO), the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD), the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> (OSCE), and the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">Organisation internationale de la Francophonie</a> (OIF). Greece's unique cultural heritage, large <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Greece" title="Tourism in Greece">tourism industry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_shipping" title="Greek shipping">prominent shipping sector</a> and geostrategic importance classify it as a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[c]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">
       <input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none">
       <div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr">
        <h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span>
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Name"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Name</span></a></li>

      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Greece" title="Name of Greece">Name of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The native name of the country in Modern Greek is <span lang="el" title="Greek-language text">Ελλάδα</span> (<i><i lang="el-Latn" title="ISO 843 Greek (Greek language) transliteration"><span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ellada.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1c/Ellada.ogg" class="internal" title="Ellada.ogg">Elláda</a></span></span></i></i>, pronounced <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[eˈlaða]</a></span>). The corresponding form in Ancient Greek and conservative formal Modern Greek (<a href="/wiki/Katharevousa" title="Katharevousa">Katharevousa</a>) is <span lang="el" title="Greek-language text">Ἑλλάς</span> (<i lang="grc-Latn" title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text">Hellas</i>, classical: <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[hel.lás]</a></span>, modern: <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[eˈlas]</a></span>). This is the source of the English alternate name <i>Hellas</i>, which is mostly found in archaic or poetic contexts today. The Greek adjectival form <span lang="el" title="Greek-language text">ελληνικός</span> (<i lang="el-Latn" title="Greek-language text">ellinikos</i>, <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[eliniˈkos]</a></span>) is sometimes also translated as <i>Hellenic</i> and is often rendered in this way in the formal names of Greek institutions, as in the official name of the Greek state, the <i>Hellenic Republic</i> (<span lang="el" title="Greek-language text">Ελληνική Δημοκρατία</span>, <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[eliniˈci ðimokraˈti.a]</a></span>).<sup id="cite_ref-:1_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-13">[12]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The English names <i>Greece</i> and <i>Greek</i> are derived, via the Latin <i><i lang="la" title="Latin-language text">Graecia</i></i> and <i><i lang="la" title="Latin-language text">Graecus</i></i>, from the name of the <a href="/wiki/Graecians" title="Graecians">Graeci</a> (<span lang="grc" title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text">Γραικοί</span>, <i lang="grc-Latn" title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text">Graikoí</i>; <small>singular</small> <span lang="grc" title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text">Γραικός</span>, <i lang="grc-Latn" title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text">Graikós</i>), who were among the first <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_Greek_tribes" title="List of ancient Greek tribes">ancient Greek tribes</a> to settle <a href="/wiki/Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia">Magna Graecia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">southern Italy</a>. The term is ultimately derived from the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_language" title="Proto-Indo-European language">Proto-Indo-European</a> root <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European/%C7%B5erh%E2%82%82-" class="extiw" title="wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European/ǵerh₂-"><span title="Proto-Indo-European language" class="Unicode" lang="ine" style="white-space:nowrap;">*ǵerh₂-</span></a></i>, "to grow old". </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Greece" title="History of Greece">History of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_early_history">Prehistory and early history</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_Greece" title="Neolithic Greece">Neolithic Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pelasgians" title="Pelasgians">Pelasgians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cycladic_culture" title="Cycladic culture">Cycladic culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minoan_civilization" title="Minoan civilization">Minoan civilization</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece" title="Mycenaean Greece">Mycenaean Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Entrance_to_the_treasure_of_Atreus.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Entrance_to_the_treasure_of_Atreus.jpg/180px-Entrance_to_the_treasure_of_Atreus.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Entrance_to_the_treasure_of_Atreus.jpg/270px-Entrance_to_the_treasure_of_Atreus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Entrance_to_the_treasure_of_Atreus.jpg/360px-Entrance_to_the_treasure_of_Atreus.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2448" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Entrance_to_the_treasure_of_Atreus.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The entrance of the <a href="/wiki/Treasury_of_Atreus" title="Treasury of Atreus">Treasury of Atreus</a> (13th BC) in <a href="/wiki/Mycenae" title="Mycenae">Mycenae</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Herodotus_Massimo_Inv124478.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Herodotus_Massimo_Inv124478.jpg/130px-Herodotus_Massimo_Inv124478.jpg" decoding="async" width="130" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Herodotus_Massimo_Inv124478.jpg/195px-Herodotus_Massimo_Inv124478.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Herodotus_Massimo_Inv124478.jpg/260px-Herodotus_Massimo_Inv124478.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2130" data-file-height="2650"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Herodotus_Massimo_Inv124478.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 484 BC</span>—<span title="circa">c.</span><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 425 BC</span>), often considered the "father of history"
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The earliest evidence of the presence of human ancestors in the southern Balkans, dated to 270,000<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>BC. It is to be found in the <a href="/wiki/Petralona_cave" title="Petralona cave">Petralona cave</a>, in the Greek province of Macedonia.<sup id="cite_ref-Borza_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Borza-24">[21]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Apidima_Cave" title="Apidima Cave">Apidima Cave</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mani_Peninsula" title="Mani Peninsula">Mani</a>, in southern Greece, contains the oldest remains of <a href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_humans" class="mw-redirect" title="Anatomically modern humans">anatomically modern humans</a> outside of Africa, dated to 210,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-20190710_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20190710-25">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PHYS-20190710_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PHYS-20190710-26">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NAT-20190710_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NAT-20190710-27">[24]</a></sup> All three stages of the Stone Age (<a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a>) are represented in Greece, for example in the <a href="/wiki/Franchthi_Cave" title="Franchthi Cave">Franchthi Cave</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[25]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> settlements in Greece, dating from the 7th millennium BC,<sup id="cite_ref-Borza_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Borza-24">[21]</a></sup> are the oldest in Europe by several centuries, as Greece lies on the route via which farming spread from the <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a> to Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[26]</a></sup> Following the end of the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_Greece" title="Neolithic Greece">Greek Neolithic period</a> in 3.200 BC, a slow transition period between the stone economy to the bronze economy during the end of the 4th Millennium BC including <a href="/wiki/Eutresis_culture" title="Eutresis culture">Eutresis culture</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Korakou_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Korakou culture (page does not exist)">Korakou culture</a> with the first large buildings (<a href="/wiki/House_of_the_Tiles" title="House of the Tiles">House of the Tiles</a>) until the middle of the 3rd Millenium BC took place in the Greek mainland.<a href="/wiki/Tiryns_culture" title="Tiryns culture">Tiryns culture</a> before the Middle Helladic period that developed the socioeconomic base of the following <a href="/wiki/Minoan_civilization" title="Minoan civilization">Minoan civilization</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mycenean_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Mycenean civilisation">Mycenean civilisation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[27]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Minoan_fresco_depicting_a_bull_leaping_scene,_found_in_Knossos,_1600-1400_BC,_Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum,_Crete_(30547636456).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Minoan_fresco_depicting_a_bull_leaping_scene%2C_found_in_Knossos%2C_1600-1400_BC%2C_Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Crete_%2830547636456%29.jpg/220px-Minoan_fresco_depicting_a_bull_leaping_scene%2C_found_in_Knossos%2C_1600-1400_BC%2C_Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Crete_%2830547636456%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="111" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Minoan_fresco_depicting_a_bull_leaping_scene%2C_found_in_Knossos%2C_1600-1400_BC%2C_Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Crete_%2830547636456%29.jpg/330px-Minoan_fresco_depicting_a_bull_leaping_scene%2C_found_in_Knossos%2C_1600-1400_BC%2C_Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Crete_%2830547636456%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Minoan_fresco_depicting_a_bull_leaping_scene%2C_found_in_Knossos%2C_1600-1400_BC%2C_Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Crete_%2830547636456%29.jpg/440px-Minoan_fresco_depicting_a_bull_leaping_scene%2C_found_in_Knossos%2C_1600-1400_BC%2C_Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Crete_%2830547636456%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4408" data-file-height="2231"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Minoan_fresco_depicting_a_bull_leaping_scene,_found_in_Knossos,_1600-1400_BC,_Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum,_Crete_(30547636456).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Fresco" title="Fresco">Fresco</a> displaying the Minoan ritual of "bull leaping", found in <a href="/wiki/Knossos" title="Knossos">Knossos</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Greece is home to the first advanced civilizations in Europe and is considered the birthplace of Western civilisation,<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[d]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Slomp2011_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Slomp2011-35">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BullietCrossley2007_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BullietCrossley2007-36">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pomeroy1999_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pomeroy1999-37">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Frucht2004_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Frucht2004-38">[34]</a></sup> beginning with the <a href="/wiki/Cycladic_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Cycladic civilization">Cycladic civilization</a> on the islands of the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean Sea</a> at around 3200 BC,<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[35]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Minoan_civilization" title="Minoan civilization">Minoan civilization</a> in Crete (2700–1500 BC),<sup id="cite_ref-Frucht2004_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Frucht2004-38">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-World_and_Its_Peoples_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_and_Its_Peoples-40">[36]</a></sup> and then the <a href="/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece" title="Mycenaean Greece">Mycenaean</a> civilization on the mainland (1600–1100 BC).<sup id="cite_ref-World_and_Its_Peoples_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_and_Its_Peoples-40">[36]</a></sup> These civilizations possessed <a href="/wiki/Writing" title="Writing">writing</a>, the Minoans using an <a href="/wiki/Undeciphered_writing_systems" title="Undeciphered writing systems">undeciphered script</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Linear_A" title="Linear A">Linear A</a>, and the Mycenaeans writing the earliest <a href="/wiki/Attested_language" title="Attested language">attested</a> form of <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> in <a href="/wiki/Linear_B" title="Linear B">Linear B</a>. The Mycenaeans gradually absorbed the Minoans, but collapsed violently around 1200 BC, along with other civilizations, during the regional event known as the <a href="/wiki/Late_Bronze_Age_collapse" title="Late Bronze Age collapse">Late Bronze Age collapse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[37]</a></sup> This ushered in a period known as the <a href="/wiki/Greek_Dark_Ages" title="Greek Dark Ages">Greek Dark Ages</a>, from which written records are absent. Though the unearthed Linear B texts are too fragmentary for the reconstruction of the political landscape and can't support the existence of a larger state, contemporary Hittite and Egyptian records suggest the presence of a single state under a "Great King" based in mainland Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[39]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Archaic_and_Classical_period">Archaic and Classical period</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Ancient Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Archaic_Greece" title="Archaic Greece">Archaic Greece</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Classical_Greece" title="Classical Greece">Classical Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Greek_Colonization_Archaic_Period.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Greek_Colonization_Archaic_Period.png/260px-Greek_Colonization_Archaic_Period.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Greek_Colonization_Archaic_Period.png/390px-Greek_Colonization_Archaic_Period.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Greek_Colonization_Archaic_Period.png/520px-Greek_Colonization_Archaic_Period.png 2x" data-file-width="684" data-file-height="388"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Greek_Colonization_Archaic_Period.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Greek territories and <a href="/wiki/Greek_colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek colonies">colonies</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Archaic_Greece" title="Archaic Greece">Archaic</a> period (750–550 BC)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The end of the Dark Ages is traditionally dated to 776 BC, the year of the first <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Olympic_Games" title="Ancient Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[40]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Iliad" title="Iliad">Iliad</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Odyssey" title="Odyssey">Odyssey</a></i>, the foundational texts of <a href="/wiki/Western_literature" title="Western literature">Western literature</a>, are believed to have been composed by <a href="/wiki/Homer" title="Homer">Homer</a> in the 7th or 8th centuries BC.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Odyssey_2003_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Odyssey_2003-46">[42]</a></sup> With the end of the Dark Ages, there emerged various kingdoms and <a href="/wiki/City-state" title="City-state">city-states</a> across the Greek peninsula, which spread to the shores of the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magna_Grecia" class="mw-redirect" title="Magna Grecia">Southern Italy</a> ("Magna Graecia") and <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Asia Minor</a>. These states and their colonies reached great levels of prosperity that resulted in an unprecedented cultural boom, that of <a href="/wiki/Classical_Greece" title="Classical Greece">classical Greece</a>, expressed in <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_ancient_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Architecture of ancient Greece">architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_ancient_Greece" title="Theatre of ancient Greece">drama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_science" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Greek science">science</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_mathematics" title="Greek mathematics">mathematics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_philosophy" title="Ancient Greek philosophy">philosophy</a>. In 508 BC, <a href="/wiki/Cleisthenes" title="Cleisthenes">Cleisthenes</a> instituted the world's first <a href="/wiki/Athenian_democracy" title="Athenian democracy">democratic</a> system of government in <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BKDunn1992_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BKDunn1992-47">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BKRaaflaud2007_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BKRaaflaud2007-48">[44]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg/220px-The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg/330px-The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg/440px-The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1144" data-file-height="804"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Parthenon_in_Athens.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Parthenon" title="Parthenon">Parthenon</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Acropolis_of_Athens" title="Acropolis of Athens">Acropolis of Athens</a>, icon of classical Greece.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By 500 BC, the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian Empire</a> controlled the Greek city states in Asia Minor and Macedonia.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[45]</a></sup> Attempts by some of the Greek city-states of Asia Minor to overthrow Persian rule <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Revolt" title="Ionian Revolt">failed</a>, and Persia <a href="/wiki/First_Persian_invasion_of_Greece" title="First Persian invasion of Greece">invaded the states of mainland Greece</a> in 492 BC, but was forced to withdraw after a defeat at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Marathon" title="Battle of Marathon">Battle of Marathon</a> in 490 BC. In response, the Greek city-states formed the Hellenic League in 481 BC, led by Sparta, which was the first historically recorded union of Greek states since the mythical union of the Trojan War.<sup id="cite_ref-Waterfield2018_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Waterfield2018-50">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fine1983_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fine1983-51">[47]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Second_Persian_invasion_of_Greece" title="Second Persian invasion of Greece">second invasion</a> by the Persians followed in 480 BC. Following decisive Greek victories in 480 and 479 BC at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Salamis" title="Battle of Salamis">Salamis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plataea" title="Battle of Plataea">Plataea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mycale" title="Battle of Mycale">Mycale</a>, the Persians were forced to withdraw for a second time, marking their eventual withdrawal from all of their European territories. Led by Athens and Sparta, the Greek victories in the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a> are considered a pivotal moment in world history,<sup id="cite_ref-Strauss2005_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Strauss2005-52">[48]</a></sup> as the 50 years of peace that followed are known as the <a href="/wiki/Fifth-century_Athens" title="Fifth-century Athens">Golden Age of Athens</a>, the seminal period of ancient Greek development that laid many of the foundations of Western civilization. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Alexander_and_Bucephalus_-_Battle_of_Issus_mosaic_-_Museo_Archeologico_Nazionale_-_Naples_BW.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Alexander_and_Bucephalus_-_Battle_of_Issus_mosaic_-_Museo_Archeologico_Nazionale_-_Naples_BW.jpg/220px-Alexander_and_Bucephalus_-_Battle_of_Issus_mosaic_-_Museo_Archeologico_Nazionale_-_Naples_BW.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Alexander_and_Bucephalus_-_Battle_of_Issus_mosaic_-_Museo_Archeologico_Nazionale_-_Naples_BW.jpg/330px-Alexander_and_Bucephalus_-_Battle_of_Issus_mosaic_-_Museo_Archeologico_Nazionale_-_Naples_BW.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Alexander_and_Bucephalus_-_Battle_of_Issus_mosaic_-_Museo_Archeologico_Nazionale_-_Naples_BW.jpg/440px-Alexander_and_Bucephalus_-_Battle_of_Issus_mosaic_-_Museo_Archeologico_Nazionale_-_Naples_BW.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3905" data-file-height="2766"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Napoli_BW_2013-05-16_16-24-01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>, whose conquests led to the <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_Age" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenistic Age">Hellenistic Age</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Lack of political unity within Greece resulted in frequent conflict between Greek states. The most devastating intra-Greek war was the <a href="/wiki/Peloponnesian_War" title="Peloponnesian War">Peloponnesian War</a> (431–404 BC), won by <a href="/wiki/Sparta" title="Sparta">Sparta</a> and marking the demise of the Athenian Empire as the leading power in ancient Greece. Both Athens and Sparta were later overshadowed by <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Thebes_(Boeotia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Thebes (Boeotia)">Thebes</a> and eventually Macedon, with the latter uniting most of the city-states of the Greek hinterland in the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Corinth" title="League of Corinth">League of Corinth</a> (also known as the <i>Hellenic League</i> or <i>Greek League</i>) under the control of <a href="/wiki/Phillip_II_of_Macedon" class="mw-redirect" title="Phillip II of Macedon">Phillip II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[49]</a></sup> Despite this development, the Greek world remained largely fragmented and would not be united under a single power until the Roman years.<sup id="cite_ref-walbank_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-walbank-54">[50]</a></sup> Sparta did not join the League and actively fought against it, raising an army led by <a href="/wiki/Agis_III" title="Agis III">Agis III</a> to secure the city-states of Crete for Persia.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[51]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MacedonEmpire.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/MacedonEmpire.jpg/260px-MacedonEmpire.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/MacedonEmpire.jpg/390px-MacedonEmpire.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/MacedonEmpire.jpg/520px-MacedonEmpire.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1990" data-file-height="951"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MacedonEmpire.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of Alexander's short-lived empire (334–323 BC). After his death the lands were divided between the <i><a href="/wiki/Diadochi" title="Diadochi">Diadochi</a></i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the assassination of Phillip II, his son <a href="/wiki/Alexander_III_of_Macedon" class="mw-redirect" title="Alexander III of Macedon">Alexander III</a> ("The Great") assumed the leadership of the League of Corinth and launched an invasion of the Persian Empire with the combined forces of the League in 334 BC. Undefeated in battle, Alexander had conquered the Persian Empire in its entirety by 330 BC. By the time of his death in 323 BC, he had created one of the largest empires in history, stretching from Greece to India. Upon his death, his empire split into several kingdoms, the most famous of which were the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Ptolemaic Egypt">Ptolemaic Egypt</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Bactrian_Kingdom" title="Greco-Bactrian Kingdom">Greco-Bactrian Kingdom</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Greeks" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Greeks">Indo-Greek Kingdom</a>. Many Greeks migrated to <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seleucia" title="Seleucia">Seleucia</a>, and the many other new Hellenistic cities in Asia and Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[52]</a></sup> Although the political unity of Alexander's empire could not be maintained, it resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenistic civilization">Hellenistic civilization</a> and spread the Greek language and Greek culture in the territories conquered by Alexander.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[53]</a></sup> Greek science, technology, and mathematics are generally considered to have reached their peak during the Hellenistic period.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[54]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span id="Hellenistic_and_Roman_periods_.28323_BC_.E2.80.93_4th_century_AD.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hellenistic_and_Roman_periods_(323_BC_–_4th_century_AD)">Hellenistic and Roman periods (323 BC – 4th century AD)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_Greece" title="Hellenistic Greece">Hellenistic Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Greece">Roman Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great" title="Wars of Alexander the Great">Wars of Alexander the Great</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:0142_-_Archaeological_Museum,_Athens_-_Antikythera_mechanism_-_Photo_by_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto,_Nov_11_2009.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/0142_-_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Athens_-_Antikythera_mechanism_-_Photo_by_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_Nov_11_2009.jpg/220px-0142_-_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Athens_-_Antikythera_mechanism_-_Photo_by_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_Nov_11_2009.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="193" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/0142_-_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Athens_-_Antikythera_mechanism_-_Photo_by_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_Nov_11_2009.jpg/330px-0142_-_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Athens_-_Antikythera_mechanism_-_Photo_by_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_Nov_11_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/0142_-_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Athens_-_Antikythera_mechanism_-_Photo_by_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_Nov_11_2009.jpg/440px-0142_-_Archaeological_Museum%2C_Athens_-_Antikythera_mechanism_-_Photo_by_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_Nov_11_2009.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2120" data-file-height="1864"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:0142_-_Archaeological_Museum,_Athens_-_Antikythera_mechanism_-_Photo_by_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto,_Nov_11_2009.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Antikythera_mechanism" title="Antikythera mechanism">Antikythera mechanism</a> (c. 100 BC) is considered to be the first known mechanical <a href="/wiki/Analog_computer" title="Analog computer">analog computer</a> (<a href="/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum,_Athens" title="National Archaeological Museum, Athens">National Archaeological Museum, Athens</a>).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Facade_of_Philip_II_tomb_Vergina_Greece.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Facade_of_Philip_II_tomb_Vergina_Greece.jpg/220px-Facade_of_Philip_II_tomb_Vergina_Greece.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Facade_of_Philip_II_tomb_Vergina_Greece.jpg/330px-Facade_of_Philip_II_tomb_Vergina_Greece.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Facade_of_Philip_II_tomb_Vergina_Greece.jpg/440px-Facade_of_Philip_II_tomb_Vergina_Greece.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Facade_of_Philip_II_tomb_Vergina_Greece.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A view from the ancient royal Macedonian tombs in <a href="/wiki/Vergina" title="Vergina">Vergina</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After a <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_the_Diadochi" title="Wars of the Diadochi">period of confusion</a> following Alexander's death, the <a href="/wiki/Antigonid_dynasty" title="Antigonid dynasty">Antigonid dynasty</a>, descended from one of Alexander's generals, established its control over Macedon and most of the Greek city-states by 276 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[55]</a></sup> From about 200 BC the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Roman Republic</a> became increasingly involved in Greek affairs and engaged in a <a href="/wiki/Macedonian_Wars" title="Macedonian Wars">series of wars with Macedon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Flower_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Flower-60">[56]</a></sup> Macedon's defeat at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Pydna" title="Battle of Pydna">Battle of Pydna</a> in 168 BC signalled the end of Antigonid power in Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[57]</a></sup> In 146 BC, Macedonia was annexed as a province by Rome, and the rest of Greece became a Roman protectorate.<sup id="cite_ref-Flower_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Flower-60">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ward_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward-62">[58]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The process was completed in 27 BC when the Roman Emperor <a href="/wiki/Augustus" title="Augustus">Augustus</a> annexed the rest of Greece and constituted it as the <a href="/wiki/Senatorial_province" title="Senatorial province">senatorial province</a> of <a href="/wiki/Achaea_(Roman_province)" title="Achaea (Roman province)">Achaea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ward_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ward-62">[58]</a></sup> Despite their military superiority, the Romans admired and became <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_world" title="Greco-Roman world">heavily influenced</a> by the achievements of Greek culture, hence <a href="/wiki/Horace" title="Horace">Horace</a>'s famous statement: <i>Graecia capta ferum victorem cepit</i> ("Greece, although captured, took its wild conqueror captive").<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[59]</a></sup> The epics of <a href="/wiki/Homer" title="Homer">Homer</a> inspired the <a href="/wiki/Aeneid" title="Aeneid">Aeneid</a> of <a href="/wiki/Virgil" title="Virgil">Virgil</a>, and authors such as <a href="/wiki/Seneca_the_younger" class="mw-redirect" title="Seneca the younger">Seneca the younger</a> wrote using Greek styles. Roman heroes such as <a href="/wiki/Scipio_Africanus" title="Scipio Africanus">Scipio Africanus</a>, tended to study <a href="/wiki/Philosophy" title="Philosophy">philosophy</a> and regarded Greek culture and science as an example to be followed. Similarly, most Roman emperors maintained an admiration for things Greek in nature. The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Emperor" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Emperor">Roman Emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Nero" title="Nero">Nero</a> visited Greece in AD 66, and performed at the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Olympic_Games" title="Ancient Olympic Games">Ancient Olympic Games</a>, despite the rules against non-Greek participation. <a href="/wiki/Hadrian" title="Hadrian">Hadrian</a> was also particularly fond of the Greeks. Before becoming emperor, he served as an <a href="/wiki/Eponymous_archon" title="Eponymous archon">eponymous archon</a> of Athens. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Athen_Odeon_Herodes_Atticus_BW_2017-10-09_13-12-44.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Athen_Odeon_Herodes_Atticus_BW_2017-10-09_13-12-44.jpg/220px-Athen_Odeon_Herodes_Atticus_BW_2017-10-09_13-12-44.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="105" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Athen_Odeon_Herodes_Atticus_BW_2017-10-09_13-12-44.jpg/330px-Athen_Odeon_Herodes_Atticus_BW_2017-10-09_13-12-44.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Athen_Odeon_Herodes_Atticus_BW_2017-10-09_13-12-44.jpg/440px-Athen_Odeon_Herodes_Atticus_BW_2017-10-09_13-12-44.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6548" data-file-height="3132"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Athen_Odeon_Herodes_Atticus_BW_2017-10-09_13-12-44.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Odeon_of_Herodes_Atticus" title="Odeon of Herodes Atticus">Odeon of Herodes Atticus</a> in Athens, built in 161 AD
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Greek-speaking communities of the Hellenised East were instrumental in the spread of early Christianity in the 2nd and 3rd centuries,<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup> and Christianity's early leaders and writers (notably <a href="/wiki/St_Paul" class="mw-redirect" title="St Paul">St. Paul</a>) were mostly Greek-speaking, though generally not from Greece itself.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> was written in Greek, and some of its sections (<a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_the_Corinthians" title="First Epistle to the Corinthians">Corinthians</a>, <a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_the_Thessalonians" title="First Epistle to the Thessalonians">Thessalonians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Philippians" title="Epistle to the Philippians">Philippians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Revelation" title="Book of Revelation">Revelation</a> of St. John of <a href="/wiki/Patmos" title="Patmos">Patmos</a>) attest to the importance of churches in Greece in <a href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Christianity">early Christianity</a>. Nevertheless, much of Greece clung tenaciously to paganism, and ancient Greek religious practices were still in vogue in the late 4th century AD,<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup> when they were outlawed by the Roman emperor <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a> in 391–392.<sup id="cite_ref-FriellWilliams2005_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FriellWilliams2005-67">[63]</a></sup> The last recorded Olympic games were held in 393,<sup id="cite_ref-Perrottet2004_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Perrottet2004-68">[64]</a></sup> and many temples were destroyed or damaged in the century that followed.<sup id="cite_ref-Evans2005_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Evans2005-69">[65]</a></sup> In Athens and rural areas, paganism is attested well into the sixth century AD<sup id="cite_ref-Evans2005_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Evans2005-69">[65]</a></sup> and even later.<sup id="cite_ref-Haldon1990_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haldon1990-70">[66]</a></sup> The closure of the <a href="/wiki/Neoplatonism" title="Neoplatonism">Neoplatonic</a> Academy of Athens by the Emperor Justinian in 529 is considered by many to mark the end of antiquity, although there is evidence that the Academy continued its activities for some time after that.<sup id="cite_ref-Evans2005_69-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Evans2005-69">[65]</a></sup> Some remote areas such as the southeastern Peloponnese remained pagan until well into the 10th century AD.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[67]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Medieval_period_.284th_.E2.80.93_15th_century.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_period_(4th_–_15th_century)">Medieval period (4th – 15th century)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Greece" title="Byzantine Greece">Byzantine Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Frankokratia" title="Frankokratia">Frankokratia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Crusade" title="Fourth Crusade">Fourth Crusade</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Hagia_Sophia_Dome.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Hagia_Sophia_Dome.png/220px-Hagia_Sophia_Dome.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="119" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Hagia_Sophia_Dome.png/330px-Hagia_Sophia_Dome.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Hagia_Sophia_Dome.png/440px-Hagia_Sophia_Dome.png 2x" data-file-width="1914" data-file-height="1031"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Hagia_Sophia_Dome.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Dome of <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia,_Thessaloniki" title="Hagia Sophia, Thessaloniki">Hagia Sophia, Thessaloniki</a> (8th century), one of the 15 <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Paleochristian_and_Byzantine_monuments_of_Thessaloniki" title="Paleochristian and Byzantine monuments of Thessaloniki">Paleochristian and Byzantine monuments of the city</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes_(9451928431).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes_%289451928431%29.jpg/220px-Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes_%289451928431%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes_%289451928431%29.jpg/330px-Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes_%289451928431%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes_%289451928431%29.jpg/440px-Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes_%289451928431%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes_(9451928431).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Grand_Master_of_the_Knights_of_Rhodes" title="Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes">Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes</a>, originally built in the late 7th century as a Byzantine citadel and beginning from 1309 used by the <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">Knights Hospitaller</a> as an administrative centre
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Roman Empire in the east, following the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Decline of the Roman Empire">fall of the Empire in the west</a> in the 5th century, is conventionally known as the Byzantine Empire (but was simply called "Kingdom of the Romans" in its own time) and lasted until 1453. With its capital in <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, its language and culture were Greek and its religion was predominantly <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Christian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[68]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From the 4th century, the Empire's Balkan territories, including Greece, suffered from the dislocation of <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">barbarian invasions</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The raids and devastation of the <a href="/wiki/Goths" title="Goths">Goths</a> and <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a> in the 4th and 5th centuries and the <a href="/wiki/South_Slavs" title="South Slavs">Slavic</a> invasion of Greece in the 7th century resulted in a dramatic collapse in imperial authority in the Greek peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFine199135–6_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFine199135–6-73">[69]</a></sup> Following the Slavic invasion, the imperial government retained formal control of only the islands and coastal areas, particularly the densely populated walled cities such as Athens, Corinth and Thessalonica, while some mountainous areas in the interior held out on their own and continued to recognise imperial authority.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFine199135–6_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFine199135–6-73">[69]</a></sup> Outside of these areas, a limited amount of Slavic settlement is generally thought to have occurred, although on a much smaller scale than previously thought.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFine199163–6_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFine199163–6-74">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[71]</a></sup> However, the view that Greece in late antiquity underwent a crisis of decline, fragmentation and depopulation is now considered outdated, as Greek cities show a high degree of institutional continuity and prosperity between the 4th and 6th centuries AD (and possibly later as well). In the early 6th century, Greece had approximately 80 cities according to the <a href="/wiki/Synecdemus" title="Synecdemus">Synecdemus</a> chronicle, and the period from the 4th to the 7th century AD is considered one of high prosperity not just in Greece but in the entire Eastern Mediterranean.<sup id="cite_ref-Rothaus2000_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rothaus2000-76">[72]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Map_Byzantine_Empire_1025-en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Map_Byzantine_Empire_1025-en.svg/330px-Map_Byzantine_Empire_1025-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="186" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Map_Byzantine_Empire_1025-en.svg/495px-Map_Byzantine_Empire_1025-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Map_Byzantine_Empire_1025-en.svg/660px-Map_Byzantine_Empire_1025-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1963" data-file-height="1104"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Map_Byzantine_Empire_1025-en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Byzantine (Eastern Roman) Empire after the death of <a href="/wiki/Basil_II" title="Basil II">Basil II</a> in 1025
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Until the 8th century almost all of modern Greece was under the jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> of <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> according to the system of <a href="/wiki/Pentarchy" title="Pentarchy">Pentarchy</a>. Byzantine <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Leo_III" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor Leo III">Emperor Leo III</a> moved the border of the <a href="/wiki/Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" class="mw-redirect" title="Patriarchate of Constantinople">Patriarchate of Constantinople</a> westward and northward in the 8th century.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[73]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Byzantine recovery of lost provinces began toward the end of the 8th century and most of the Greek peninsula came under imperial control again, in stages, during the 9th century.<sup id="cite_ref-EB2_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB2-78">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFine199179–83_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFine199179–83-79">[75]</a></sup> This process was facilitated by a large influx of Greeks from Sicily and Asia Minor to the Greek peninsula, while at the same time many Slavs were captured and re-settled in Asia Minor and the few that remained were assimilated.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFine199163–6_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFine199163–6-74">[70]</a></sup> During the 11th and 12th centuries the return of stability resulted in the Greek peninsula benefiting from strong economic growth&nbsp;– much stronger than that of the Anatolian territories of the Empire.<sup id="cite_ref-EB2_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB2-78">[74]</a></sup> During that time, the <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">Greek Orthodox Church</a> was also instrumental in the spread of Greek ideas to the wider <a href="/wiki/Orthodoxy" title="Orthodoxy">Orthodox world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BritIdent_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BritIdent-80">[76]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="A complete citation is needed. (September 2018)">full citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Crusade" title="Fourth Crusade">Fourth Crusade</a> and the fall of Constantinople to the "<a href="/wiki/Latin_Empire" title="Latin Empire">Latins</a>" in 1204, mainland Greece was split between the Greek <a href="/wiki/Despotate_of_Epirus#Foundation" title="Despotate of Epirus">Despotate of Epirus</a> (a Byzantine successor state) and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_France" title="Kingdom of France">French</a> rule<sup id="cite_ref-EB3_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB3-81">[77]</a></sup> (known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Frankokratia" title="Frankokratia">Frankokratia</a></i>), while some islands came under <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Venetian</a> rule.<sup id="cite_ref-EB3A_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB3A-82">[78]</a></sup> The re-establishment of the Byzantine imperial capital in Constantinople in 1261 was accompanied by the empire's recovery of much of the Greek peninsula, although the Frankish <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Achaea" title="Principality of Achaea">Principality of Achaea</a> in the Peloponnese and the rival Greek <a href="/wiki/Despotate_of_Epirus" title="Despotate of Epirus">Despotate of Epirus</a> in the north both remained important regional powers into the 14th century, while the islands remained largely under Genoese and Venetian control.<sup id="cite_ref-EB3_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB3-81">[77]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire_under_the_Palaiologos_dynasty" title="Byzantine Empire under the Palaiologos dynasty">Paleologi dynasty</a> (1261–1453) a new era of Greek patriotism emerged accompanied by a turning back to ancient Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-Vasiliev_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vasiliev-83">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RuncimanRunciman1985_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RuncimanRunciman1985-85">[81]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As such prominent personalities at the time also proposed changing the imperial title to "Emperor of the Hellenes",<sup id="cite_ref-Vasiliev_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vasiliev-83">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RuncimanRunciman1985_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RuncimanRunciman1985-85">[81]</a></sup> and, in late fourteenth century, the emperor was frequently referred to as the "Emperor of the Hellenes".<sup id="cite_ref-CareyCarey1968_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CareyCarey1968-86">[82]</a></sup> Similarly, in several international treaties of that time the Byzantine emperor is styled as "Imperator Graecorum".<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[83]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 14th century, much of the Greek peninsula was lost by the Byzantine Empire at first to the <a href="/wiki/Serbs" title="Serbs">Serbs</a> and then to the <a href="/wiki/Ottomans" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottomans">Ottomans</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EB4_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB4-88">[84]</a></sup> By the beginning of the 15th century, the Ottoman advance meant that Byzantine territory in Greece was limited mainly to its then-largest city, Thessaloniki, and the Peloponnese (<a href="/wiki/Despotate_of_the_Morea" title="Despotate of the Morea">Despotate of the Morea</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-EB4_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB4-88">[84]</a></sup> After the fall of Constantinople to the Ottomans in 1453, the Morea was one of the last remnants of the Byzantine Empire to hold out against the Ottomans. However, this, too, fell to the Ottomans in 1460, completing the Ottoman conquest of mainland Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-EB5_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB5-89">[85]</a></sup> With the Turkish conquest, many Byzantine Greek scholars, who up until then were largely responsible for preserving <a href="/wiki/Classical_Greece" title="Classical Greece">Classical Greek</a> knowledge, fled to the West, taking with them a large body of literature and thereby significantly <a href="/wiki/Greek_scholars_in_the_Renaissance" title="Greek scholars in the Renaissance">contributing to the Renaissance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-JJN_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JJN-90">[86]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Venetian_possessions_and_Ottoman_rule_.2815th_century_.E2.80.93_1821.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Venetian_possessions_and_Ottoman_rule_(15th_century_–_1821)">Venetian possessions and Ottoman rule (15th century – 1821)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Greece" title="Ottoman Greece">Ottoman Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stato_da_M%C3%A0r" title="Stato da Màr">Stato da Màr</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Phanariotes" class="mw-redirect" title="Phanariotes">Phanariotes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Candia" title="Kingdom of Candia">Kingdom of Candia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Islands_under_Venetian_rule" class="mw-redirect" title="Ionian Islands under Venetian rule">Ionian Islands under Venetian rule</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Angelokastro_(Corfu).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Angelokastro_%28Corfu%29.jpg/220px-Angelokastro_%28Corfu%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Angelokastro_%28Corfu%29.jpg/330px-Angelokastro_%28Corfu%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Angelokastro_%28Corfu%29.jpg/440px-Angelokastro_%28Corfu%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Angelokastro_(Corfu).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a> castle of <a href="/wiki/Angelokastro_(Corfu)" title="Angelokastro (Corfu)">Angelokastro</a> successfully repulsed the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottomans</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Corfu_(1537)" title="Siege of Corfu (1537)">First Great Siege of Corfu in 1537</a>, the siege of 1571, and the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Corfu_(1716)" title="Siege of Corfu (1716)">Second Great Siege of Corfu in 1716</a>, causing them to abandon their plans to conquer <a href="/wiki/Corfu" title="Corfu">Corfu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Stamatopoulos1993_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stamatopoulos1993-91">[87]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>While most of mainland Greece and the Aegean islands was under Ottoman control by the end of the 15th century, <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crete" title="Crete">Crete</a> remained <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Venetian</a> territory and did not fall to the Ottomans until 1571 and 1670 respectively. The only part of the Greek-speaking world that escaped long-term Ottoman rule was the <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Islands" title="Ionian Islands">Ionian Islands</a>, which remained Venetian until their capture by the <a href="/wiki/First_French_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="First French Republic">First French Republic</a> in 1797, then passed to the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom</a> in 1809 until their unification with Greece in 1864.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClogg199210_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClogg199210-92">[88]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>While some Greeks in the Ionian Islands and <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> lived in prosperity, and Greeks of Constantinople (<a href="/wiki/Phanariotes" class="mw-redirect" title="Phanariotes">Phanariotes</a>) achieved positions of power within the Ottoman administration,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClogg1992page_23_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClogg1992page_23-93">[89]</a></sup> much of the population of mainland Greece suffered the economic consequences of the Ottoman conquest. Heavy taxes were enforced, and in later years the Ottoman Empire enacted a policy of creation of hereditary estates, effectively turning the rural Greek populations into <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">serfs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[90]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">Greek Orthodox Church</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople</a> were considered by the Ottoman governments as the ruling authorities of the entire <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox Christian</a> population of the Ottoman Empire, whether ethnically Greek or not. Although the Ottoman state did not force non-Muslims to convert to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, Christians faced several types of discrimination intended to highlight their inferior status in the Ottoman Empire. Discrimination against Christians, particularly when combined with harsh treatment by local Ottoman authorities, led to conversions to Islam, if only superficially. In the 19th century, many "crypto-Christians" returned to their old religious allegiance.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClogg199214_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClogg199214-95">[91]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:White_Tower_and_Beach_front.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/White_Tower_and_Beach_front.jpg/220px-White_Tower_and_Beach_front.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/White_Tower_and_Beach_front.jpg/330px-White_Tower_and_Beach_front.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/White_Tower_and_Beach_front.jpg/440px-White_Tower_and_Beach_front.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="853"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:White_Tower_and_Beach_front.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/White_Tower_of_Thessaloniki" title="White Tower of Thessaloniki">White Tower of Thessaloniki</a>, one of the best-known Ottoman structures remaining in Greece.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The nature of Ottoman administration of Greece varied, though it was invariably arbitrary and often harsh.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClogg199214_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClogg199214-95">[91]</a></sup> Some cities had governors appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Sultan" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Sultan">Sultan</a>, while others (like Athens) were self-governed municipalities. Mountainous regions in the interior and many islands remained effectively autonomous from the central Ottoman state for many centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClogg1992_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClogg1992-96">[92]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (March 2013)">page&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>When military conflicts broke out between the Ottoman Empire and other states, Greeks usually took up arms against the Ottomans, with few exceptions.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Prior to the Greek Revolution of 1821, there had been a number of wars which saw Greeks fight against the Ottomans, such as the Greek participation in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lepanto" title="Battle of Lepanto">Battle of Lepanto</a> in 1571, the Epirus peasants' revolts of 1600–1601 (led by the Orthodox bishop <a href="/wiki/Dionysios_Skylosophos" title="Dionysios Skylosophos">Dionysios Skylosophos</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Morean_War" title="Morean War">Morean War</a> of 1684–1699, and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian</a>-instigated <a href="/wiki/Orlov_Revolt" class="mw-redirect" title="Orlov Revolt">Orlov Revolt</a> in 1770, which aimed at breaking up the Ottoman Empire in favour of Russian interests.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClogg1992_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClogg1992-96">[92]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (March 2013)">page&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup> These uprisings were put down by the Ottomans with great bloodshed.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[94]</a></sup> On the other side, many Greeks were conscripted as Ottoman citizens to serve in the Ottoman army (and especially the Ottoman navy), while also the <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople</a>, responsible for the Orthodox, remained in general loyal to the empire. </p>
      <p>The 16th and 17th centuries are regarded as something of a "dark age" in Greek history, with the prospect of overthrowing Ottoman rule appearing remote with only the Ionian islands remaining free of Turkish domination. <a href="/wiki/Corfu" title="Corfu">Corfu</a> withstood three major sieges in <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Corfu_(1537)" title="Siege of Corfu (1537)">1537</a>, 1571 and <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Corfu_(1716)#The_Siege_of_Corfu" title="Siege of Corfu (1716)">1716</a> all of which resulted in the repulsion of the Ottomans. However, in the 18th century, due to their mastery of shipping and commerce, a wealthy and dispersed Greek merchant class arose. These merchants came to dominate trade within the Ottoman Empire, establishing communities throughout the Mediterranean, the Balkans, and Western Europe. Though the Ottoman conquest had cut Greece off from significant European intellectual movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a>, these ideas together with the ideals of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romantic_nationalism" title="Romantic nationalism">romantic nationalism</a> began to penetrate the Greek world via the mercantile diaspora.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClogg199227_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClogg199227-99">[95]</a></sup> In the late 18th century, <a href="/wiki/Rigas_Feraios" title="Rigas Feraios">Rigas Feraios</a>, the first revolutionary to envision an independent Greek state, published a series of documents relating to Greek independence, including but not limited to a national anthem and the first detailed map of Greece, in <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a>. Feraios was murdered by Ottoman agents in 1798.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClogg199231_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClogg199231-100">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[97]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_period">Modern period</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_modern_Greece" title="History of modern Greece">History of modern Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <h4><span id="Greek_War_of_Independence_.281821.E2.80.931832.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Greek_War_of_Independence_(1821–1832)">Greek War of Independence (1821–1832)</span></h4> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Greece&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Greek_War_of_Independence" title="Greek War of Independence">Greek War of Independence</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
