       See also: <a href="/wiki/Modern_Greek_Enlightenment" title="Modern Greek Enlightenment">Modern Greek Enlightenment</a>, <a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Greek_Declaration_of_Independence" class="extiw" title="wikisource:Greek Declaration of Independence">Greek Declaration of Independence</a>, and <a href="/wiki/First_Hellenic_Republic" title="First Hellenic Republic">First Hellenic Republic</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_sortie_of_Messologhi_by_Theodore_Vryzakis.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/The_sortie_of_Messologhi_by_Theodore_Vryzakis.jpg/220px-The_sortie_of_Messologhi_by_Theodore_Vryzakis.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="308" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/The_sortie_of_Messologhi_by_Theodore_Vryzakis.jpg/330px-The_sortie_of_Messologhi_by_Theodore_Vryzakis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/The_sortie_of_Messologhi_by_Theodore_Vryzakis.jpg/440px-The_sortie_of_Messologhi_by_Theodore_Vryzakis.jpg 2x" data-file-width="465" data-file-height="650"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_sortie_of_Messologhi_by_Theodore_Vryzakis.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>The sortie (exodus) of <a href="/wiki/Messolonghi" class="mw-redirect" title="Messolonghi">Messolonghi</a></i>, depicting the <a href="/wiki/Third_Siege_of_Missolonghi" class="mw-redirect" title="Third Siege of Missolonghi">Third Siege of Missolonghi</a>, painted by <a href="/wiki/Theodoros_Vryzakis" title="Theodoros Vryzakis">Theodoros Vryzakis</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Navarino.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Navarino.jpg/220px-Navarino.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Navarino.jpg/330px-Navarino.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Navarino.jpg/440px-Navarino.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1990" data-file-height="1260"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Naval_Battle_of_Navarino_by_Garneray.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Navarino" title="Battle of Navarino">Battle of Navarino</a> in 1827 secured Greek independence.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the late eighteenth century, an increase in secular learning during the <a href="/wiki/Modern_Greek_Enlightenment" title="Modern Greek Enlightenment">Modern Greek Enlightenment</a> led to the revival among Greeks of the diaspora of the <a href="/wiki/Greek_nationalism" title="Greek nationalism">notion of a Greek nation</a> tracing its existence to <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">ancient Greece</a>, distinct from the other Orthodox peoples, and having a right to political autonomy. One of the organizations formed in this intellectual milieu was the <a href="/wiki/Filiki_Eteria" title="Filiki Eteria">Filiki Eteria</a>, a secret organization formed by merchants in <a href="/wiki/Odessa" title="Odessa">Odessa</a> in 1814.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[98]</a></sup> Appropriating a long-standing tradition of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> messianic prophecy aspiring to the resurrection of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Roman empire">eastern Roman empire</a> and creating the impression they had the backing of <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Tsarist Russia</a>, they managed amidst a crisis of Ottoman trade, from 1815 onwards, to engage traditional strata of the Greek Orthodox world in their liberal nationalist cause.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[99]</a></sup> The Filiki Eteria planned to launch revolution in the <a href="/wiki/Peloponnese" title="Peloponnese">Peloponnese</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Danubian_Principalities" title="Danubian Principalities">Danubian Principalities</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>. The first of these revolts began on 6 March 1821 in the Danubian Principalities under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Ypsilantis_(1792%E2%80%931828)" class="mw-redirect" title="Alexander Ypsilantis (1792–1828)">Alexandros Ypsilantis</a>, but it was soon put down by the Ottomans. The events in the north spurred the Greeks of the Peloponnese into action and on 17 March 1821 the <a href="/wiki/Maniots" title="Maniots">Maniots</a> declared war on the Ottomans.<sup id="cite_ref-Brewer,_D._2001,_pp._235_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brewer,_D._2001,_pp._235-104">[100]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By the end of the month, the Peloponnese was in open revolt against the Ottomans and by October 1821 the Greeks under <a href="/wiki/Theodoros_Kolokotronis" title="Theodoros Kolokotronis">Theodoros Kolokotronis</a> had captured <a href="/wiki/Tripoli,_Greece" title="Tripoli, Greece">Tripolitsa</a>. The Peloponnesian revolt was quickly followed by revolts in <a href="/wiki/Crete" title="Crete">Crete</a>, <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(Greece)" title="Macedonia (Greece)">Macedonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Greece" title="Central Greece">Central Greece</a>, which would soon be suppressed. Meanwhile, the makeshift Greek navy was achieving success against the Ottoman navy in the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean Sea</a> and prevented Ottoman reinforcements from arriving by sea. In 1822 and 1824 the Turks and Egyptians ravaged the islands, including <a href="/wiki/Chios_Massacre" class="mw-redirect" title="Chios Massacre">Chios</a> and <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_Psara" class="mw-redirect" title="Destruction of Psara">Psara</a>, committing wholesale <a href="/wiki/Massacres_during_the_Greek_Revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Massacres during the Greek Revolution">massacres</a> of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-Brewer,_D._2001,_pp._235_104-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brewer,_D._2001,_pp._235-104">[100]</a></sup> Approximately three-quarters of the <a href="/wiki/Chios" title="Chios">Chios</a>' Greek population of 120,000 were <a href="/wiki/Chios_massacre" title="Chios massacre">killed, enslaved</a> or died of disease.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[102]</a></sup> This had the effect of galvanizing public opinion in western Europe in favour of the Greek rebels.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[103]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Tensions soon developed among different Greek factions, leading to two consecutive civil wars. Meanwhile, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Sultan" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Sultan">Ottoman Sultan</a> negotiated with <a href="/wiki/Mehmet_Ali_of_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Mehmet Ali of Egypt">Mehmet Ali of Egypt</a>, who agreed to send his son <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_Pasha_of_Egypt" title="Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt">Ibrahim Pasha</a> to Greece with an army to suppress the revolt in return for territorial gain.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[104]</a></sup> Ibrahim landed in the Peloponnese in February 1825 and had immediate success: by the end of 1825, most of the Peloponnese was under Egyptian control, and the city of <a href="/wiki/Missolonghi" title="Missolonghi">Missolonghi</a>—put under siege by the Turks since April 1825—fell in April 1826. Although Ibrahim was defeated in <a href="/wiki/Mani_Peninsula" title="Mani Peninsula">Mani</a>, he had succeeded in suppressing most of the revolt in the Peloponnese, and Athens had been retaken. </p>
      <p>After years of negotiation, three <a href="/wiki/Great_powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Great powers">great powers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bourbon_Restoration_in_France" title="Bourbon Restoration in France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, decided to intervene in the conflict and each nation sent a navy to Greece. Following news that combined Ottoman–Egyptian fleets were going to attack the Greek island of <a href="/wiki/Hydra,_Saronic_Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydra, Saronic Islands">Hydra</a>, the allied fleet intercepted the Ottoman–Egyptian fleet at <a href="/wiki/Pylos" title="Pylos">Navarino</a>. A week-long standoff ended with the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Navarino" title="Battle of Navarino">Battle of Navarino</a> (20 October 1827) which resulted in the destruction of the Ottoman–Egyptian fleet. A <a href="/wiki/Morea_expedition" title="Morea expedition">French expeditionary force</a> was dispatched to supervise the evacuation of the Egyptian army from the Peloponnese, while the Greeks proceeded to the captured part of Central Greece by 1828. As a result of years of negotiation, the <a href="/wiki/First_Hellenic_Republic" title="First Hellenic Republic">nascent Greek state</a> was finally recognised under the <a href="/wiki/London_Protocol_(1830)" title="London Protocol (1830)">London Protocol</a> in 1830. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Kingdom_of_Greece">Kingdom of Greece</span></h4> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Greece&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece" title="Kingdom of Greece">Kingdom of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg/260px-Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg/390px-Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg/520px-Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1210" data-file-height="724"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Peter_von_Hess_-_The_Entry_of_King_Othon_of_Greece_in_Athens_-_WGA11387.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>The Entry of <a href="/wiki/Otto_of_Greece" title="Otto of Greece">King Otto</a> in Athens</i>, painted by <a href="/wiki/Peter_von_Hess" title="Peter von Hess">Peter von Hess</a> in 1839.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1827, <a href="/wiki/Ioannis_Kapodistrias" title="Ioannis Kapodistrias">Ioannis Kapodistrias</a>, from <a href="/wiki/Corfu" title="Corfu">Corfu</a>, was chosen by the <a href="/wiki/Third_National_Assembly_at_Troezen" title="Third National Assembly at Troezen">Third National Assembly at Troezen</a> as the first governor of the <a href="/wiki/First_Hellenic_Republic" title="First Hellenic Republic">First Hellenic Republic</a>. Kapodistrias established a series of state, economic and military institutions. Soon tensions appeared between him and local interests. Following his assassination in 1831 and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/London_Conference_of_1832" title="London Conference of 1832">London conference</a> a year later, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Power" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Power">Great Powers</a> of Britain, France and Russia installed Bavarian Prince <a href="/wiki/Otto_of_Greece" title="Otto of Greece">Otto von Wittelsbach</a> as <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece_(Wittelsbach)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Greece (Wittelsbach)">monarch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_otto_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica_otto-109">[105]</a></sup> Otto's reign was <a href="/wiki/Despotism" title="Despotism">despotic</a>, and in its first 11 years of independence Greece was ruled by a Bavarian oligarchy led by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Ludwig_von_Armansperg" class="mw-redirect" title="Joseph Ludwig von Armansperg">Joseph Ludwig von Armansperg</a> as <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Greece" title="Prime Minister of Greece">Prime Minister</a> and, later, by Otto himself, who held the title of both King and Premier.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_otto_109-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica_otto-109">[105]</a></sup> Throughout this period Greece remained under the influence of its three protecting <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">Great Powers</a>, <a href="/wiki/July_Monarchy" title="July Monarchy">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russia</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bavaria" title="Kingdom of Bavaria">Bavaria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[106]</a></sup> In 1843 an uprising forced Otto to grant a constitution and a representative assembly. </p>
      <p>Despite the <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolutism</a> of Otto's reign, the early years proved instrumental in creating institutions which are still the bedrock of Greek administration and education.<sup id="cite_ref-encyclopedia_imperialism_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encyclopedia_imperialism-111">[107]</a></sup> Important steps were taken in the creation of the education system, maritime and postal communications, effective civil administration and, most importantly, the <a href="/wiki/Legal_code" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal code">legal code</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreat_Greek_Encyclopedia50-51_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreat_Greek_Encyclopedia50-51-112">[108]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Historical_revisionism" title="Historical revisionism">Historical revisionism</a> took the form of de-<a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantinification</a> and de-<a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottomanisation</a>, in favour of promoting the country's <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Ancient Greek</a> heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-roudometof_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roudometof-113">[109]</a></sup> In this spirit, the national capital was moved from <a href="/wiki/Nafplio" title="Nafplio">Nafplio</a>, where it had been since 1829, to <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a>, which was at the time a village.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[110]</a></sup> Religious reform also took place, and the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Greece" title="Church of Greece">Church of Greece</a> was established as Greece's <a href="/wiki/National_church" title="National church">national church</a>, although Otto remained a <a href="/wiki/Catholic_church" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic church">Catholic</a>. 25 March, the day of <a href="/wiki/Annunciation" title="Annunciation">Annunciation</a>, was chosen as the anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/Greek_War_of_Independence" title="Greek War of Independence">Greek War of Independence</a> in order to reinforce the link between Greek identity and <a href="/wiki/Orthodoxy" title="Orthodoxy">Orthodoxy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-roudometof_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roudometof-113">[109]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pavlos_Karolidis" title="Pavlos Karolidis">Pavlos Karolidis</a> called the Bavarian efforts to create a modern state in Greece as "not only appropriate for the peoples' needs, but also based on excellent administrative principles of the era".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreat_Greek_Encyclopedia50-51_112-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreat_Greek_Encyclopedia50-51-112">[108]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Otto was deposed in the <a href="/wiki/23_October_1862_Revolution" title="23 October 1862 Revolution">23 October 1862 Revolution</a>. Multiple causes led to his deposition and exile, including the Bavarian-dominated government, heavy taxation, and a failed attempt to annex <a href="/wiki/Crete" title="Crete">Crete</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_otto_109-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica_otto-109">[105]</a></sup> The catalyst for the revolt was Otto's dismissal of <a href="/wiki/Konstantinos_Kanaris" title="Konstantinos Kanaris">Konstantinos Kanaris</a> from the Premiership.<sup id="cite_ref-encyclopedia_imperialism_111-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encyclopedia_imperialism-111">[107]</a></sup> A year later, he was replaced by Prince Wilhelm (William) of Denmark, who took the name <a href="/wiki/George_I_of_Greece" title="George I of Greece">George I</a> and brought with him the Ionian Islands as a coronation gift from Britain. A <a href="/wiki/Greek_Constitution_of_1864" title="Greek Constitution of 1864">new Constitution in 1864</a> changed Greece's form of government from <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> to the more democratic <a href="/wiki/Crowned_republic" title="Crowned republic">crowned republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreat_Greek_Encyclopedia239&quot;Διὰ_τοῦ_Συντάγματος_τοῦ_1864_καθιερώθει_ὡς_πολίτευμα_διὰ_τὴν_Ἑλλάδα_ἡ_κοινοβουλευτικὴ_μοναρχία,_ἣ,_ὅπως_ἄλλως_ἐχαρακτηρίσθη,_ἡ_«βασιλευομένη_δημοκρατία»_ἣ_«δημοκρατικὴ_βασιλεία»&quot;_[Through_the_Constitution_of_1864,_constitutional_monarchy,_or,_as_it_had_been_described,_&quot;crowned_democracy&quot;,_or_&quot;democratic_monarchy&quot;,_was_consolidated_as_the_form_of_government_in_Greece]_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreat_Greek_Encyclopedia239&quot;Διὰ_τοῦ_Συντάγματος_τοῦ_1864_καθιερώθει_ὡς_πολίτευμα_διὰ_τὴν_Ἑλλάδα_ἡ_κοινοβουλευτικὴ_μοναρχία,_ἣ,_ὅπως_ἄλλως_ἐχαρακτηρίσθη,_ἡ_«βασιλευομένη_δημοκρατία»_ἣ_«δημοκρατικὴ_βασιλεία»&quot;_[Through_the_Constitution_of_1864,_constitutional_monarchy,_or,_as_it_had_been_described,_&quot;crowned_democracy&quot;,_or_&quot;democratic_monarchy&quot;,_was_consolidated_as_the_form_of_government_in_Greece]-115">[111]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[113]</a></sup> In 1875 the concept of <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_majority" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliamentary majority">parliamentary majority</a> as a requirement for the formation of a government was introduced by <a href="/wiki/Charilaos_Trikoupis" title="Charilaos Trikoupis">Charilaos Trikoupis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-constitutional_history_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constitutional_history-118">[114]</a></sup> curbing the power of the monarchy to appoint <a href="/wiki/Minority_government" title="Minority government">minority governments</a> of its preference. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Map_Greece_expansion_1832-1947-en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Map_Greece_expansion_1832-1947-en.svg/260px-Map_Greece_expansion_1832-1947-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="342" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Map_Greece_expansion_1832-1947-en.svg/390px-Map_Greece_expansion_1832-1947-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Map_Greece_expansion_1832-1947-en.svg/520px-Map_Greece_expansion_1832-1947-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="730" data-file-height="959"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Map_Greece_expansion_1832-1947-en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The territorial evolution of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece" title="Kingdom of Greece">Kingdom of Greece</a> from 1832 to 1947.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Corruption, coupled with Trikoupis' increased spending to fund infrastructure projects like the <a href="/wiki/Corinth_Canal" title="Corinth Canal">Corinth Canal</a>, overtaxed the weak Greek economy and forced the declaration of <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_default" title="Sovereign default">public insolvency</a> in 1893. Greece also accepted the imposition of an International Financial Control authority to pay off the country's debtors. Another political issue in 19th-century Greece was uniquely Greek: the language question. The Greek people spoke a form of Greek called <a href="/wiki/Modern_Greek" title="Modern Greek">Demotic</a>. Many of the educated elite saw this as a peasant dialect and were determined to restore the glories of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a>. </p>
      <p>Government documents and newspapers were consequently published in <i><a href="/wiki/Katharevousa" title="Katharevousa">Katharevousa</a></i> (purified) Greek, a form which few ordinary Greeks could read. Liberals favoured recognising Demotic as the national language, but conservatives and the Orthodox Church resisted all such efforts, to the extent that, when the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> was translated into Demotic in 1901, riots erupted in Athens and the government fell (the <i>Evangeliaka</i>). This issue would continue to plague Greek politics until the 1970s. </p>
      <p>All Greeks were united, however, in their determination to liberate the <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_ancient_Greece" title="Regions of ancient Greece">Hellenic lands</a> under Ottoman rule. Especially in <a href="/wiki/Crete" title="Crete">Crete</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Cretan_Revolt_(1866%E2%80%931869)" class="mw-redirect" title="Cretan Revolt (1866–1869)">prolonged revolt in 1866–1869</a> had raised nationalist fervour. When war broke out between <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)">Russia and the Ottomans in 1877</a>, Greek popular sentiment rallied to Russia's side, but Greece was too poor and too concerned about British intervention, to officially enter the war. Nevertheless, in 1881, <a href="/wiki/Thessaly" title="Thessaly">Thessaly</a> and small parts of <a href="/wiki/Epirus_(region)" title="Epirus (region)">Epirus</a> were ceded to Greece as part of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Berlin,_1878" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Berlin, 1878">Treaty of Berlin</a>, while frustrating Greek hopes of receiving Crete. </p>
      <p>Greeks in Crete continued to stage regular revolts, and in 1897, the Greek government under Theodoros Deligiannis, bowing to popular pressure, declared war on the Ottomans. In the ensuing <a href="/wiki/Greco-Turkish_War_(1897)" title="Greco-Turkish War (1897)">Greco-Turkish War of 1897</a>, the badly trained and equipped Greek army was defeated by the Ottomans. Through the intervention of the Great Powers, however, Greece lost only a little territory along the border to Turkey, while Crete was established as an <a href="/wiki/Cretan_State" title="Cretan State">autonomous state</a> under <a href="/wiki/Prince_George_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Prince George of Greece">Prince George of Greece</a>. With state coffers empty, fiscal policy came under <a href="/wiki/International_Financial_Control" title="International Financial Control">International Financial Control</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Alarmed by the abortive <a href="/wiki/Ilinden_uprising" class="mw-redirect" title="Ilinden uprising">Ilinden uprising</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Autonomism_(political_doctrine)" title="Autonomism (political doctrine)">autonomist</a> <a href="/wiki/Internal_Macedonian_Revolutionary_Organization" title="Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization">Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization</a> (IMRO) in 1903, the Greek government, aiming to quell <a href="/wiki/Komitadjis" class="mw-redirect" title="Komitadjis">Komitadjis</a> (IMRO bands) and detach the <a href="/wiki/Slavic_speakers_in_Ottoman_Macedonia" title="Slavic speakers in Ottoman Macedonia">Slavophone peasants of the region</a> from <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Macedonians" class="mw-redirect" title="Bulgarian Macedonians">Bulgarian</a> influence, sponsored a <a href="/wiki/Guerrilla_warfare" title="Guerrilla warfare">guerrilla</a> campaign in Ottoman-ruled <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(region)" title="Macedonia (region)">Macedonia</a>, led by Greek officers and known as the <a href="/wiki/Macedonian_Struggle" title="Macedonian Struggle">Macedonian Struggle</a>, which ended with the <a href="/wiki/Young_Turk_Revolution" title="Young Turk Revolution">Young Turk Revolution</a> in 1908.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[115]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span id="Expansion.2C_disaster.2C_and_reconstruction"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Expansion,_disaster,_and_reconstruction">Expansion, disaster, and reconstruction</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Greece_in_the_Balkan_Wars" title="Greece in the Balkan Wars">Greece in the Balkan Wars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greece_in_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Greece in World War I">Greece in World War I</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Schism" title="National Schism">National Schism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia_Minor_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Asia Minor Campaign">Asia Minor Campaign</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Second_Hellenic_Republic" title="Second Hellenic Republic">Second Hellenic Republic</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Greek_Parade_Paris_1919.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Greek_Parade_Paris_1919.jpg/220px-Greek_Parade_Paris_1919.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Greek_Parade_Paris_1919.jpg/330px-Greek_Parade_Paris_1919.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Greek_Parade_Paris_1919.jpg/440px-Greek_Parade_Paris_1919.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1072" data-file-height="769"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Greek_Parade_Paris_1919.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Hellenic Army formation in the <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> Victory Parade in <a href="/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe" title="Arc de Triomphe">Arc de Triomphe</a>, Paris, July 1919.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Amidst general dissatisfaction with the seeming inertia and unattainability of <a href="/wiki/Megali_Idea" title="Megali Idea">national aspirations</a> under the premiership of the cautious reformist <a href="/wiki/Georgios_Theotokis" title="Georgios Theotokis">Theotokis</a>, a group of military officers organised a <a href="/wiki/Goudi_coup" title="Goudi coup">coup</a> in August 1909 and shortly thereafter called to Athens <a href="/wiki/Cretan_State" title="Cretan State">Cretan</a> politician <a href="/wiki/Eleftherios_Venizelos" title="Eleftherios Venizelos">Eleftherios Venizelos</a>, who conveyed a vision of national regeneration. After winning <a href="/wiki/Greek_legislative_election,_August_1910" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek legislative election, August 1910">two</a> <a href="/wiki/Greek_legislative_election,_November_1910" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek legislative election, November 1910">elections</a> and becoming Prime Minister in 1910,<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[116]</a></sup> Venizelos initiated wide-ranging fiscal, social, and <a href="/wiki/Greek_Constitution_of_1911" title="Greek Constitution of 1911">constitutional reforms</a>, reorganised the military, made Greece a member of the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_League" title="Balkan League">Balkan League</a>, and led the country through the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Wars" title="Balkan Wars">Balkan Wars</a>. By 1913, Greece's territory and population had almost doubled, annexing <a href="/wiki/Crete" title="Crete">Crete</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epirus_(region)" title="Epirus (region)">Epirus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(Greece)" title="Macedonia (Greece)">Macedonia</a>. In the following years, the struggle between <a href="/wiki/Constantine_I_of_Greece" title="Constantine I of Greece">King Constantine I</a> and charismatic Venizelos over the country's foreign policy on the eve of <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a> dominated the country's political scene and divided the country into <a href="/wiki/National_Schism" title="National Schism">two opposing groups</a>. During parts of WW1, Greece had two governments: A royalist <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">pro-German</a> one in <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Venizelism" title="Venizelism">Venizelist</a> pro-<a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Entente</a> one in <a href="/wiki/Thessaloniki" title="Thessaloniki">Thessaloniki</a>. The two governments were united in 1917, when Greece officially entered the war on the side of the Entente. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Greece_in_the_Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Greece_in_the_Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres.jpg/220px-Greece_in_the_Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Greece_in_the_Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres.jpg/330px-Greece_in_the_Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Greece_in_the_Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres.jpg/440px-Greece_in_the_Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1054" data-file-height="750"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Greece_in_the_Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of Greater Greece after the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">Treaty of Sèvres</a>, when the <i><a href="/wiki/Megali_Idea" title="Megali Idea">Megali Idea</a></i> seemed close to fulfillment, featuring <a href="/wiki/Eleftherios_Venizelos" title="Eleftherios Venizelos">Eleftherios Venizelos</a> as its supervising genius.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the aftermath of World War I, Greece attempted further expansion into <a href="/wiki/Asia_Minor" class="mw-redirect" title="Asia Minor">Asia Minor</a>, a region with a large native Greek population at the time, but was defeated in the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Turkish_War_(1919%E2%80%9322)" class="mw-redirect" title="Greco-Turkish War (1919–22)">Greco-Turkish War of 1919–1922</a>, contributing to a massive flight of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Greeks" title="Ottoman Greeks">Asia Minor Greeks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Gibney_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gibney-121">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[118]</a></sup> These events overlapped, with both happening during the <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greek genocide</a> (1914–1922),<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[119]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[122]</a></sup> a period during which, according to various sources,<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[123]</a></sup> Ottoman and Turkish officials contributed to the death of several hundred thousand Asia Minor Greeks, along with similar numbers of <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" class="mw-redirect" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrians</a> and a rather larger number of <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenians</a>. The resultant Greek exodus from Asia Minor was made permanent, and expanded, in an official <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">Population exchange between Greece and Turkey</a>. The exchange was part of the terms of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> which ended the war.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[124]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The following era was marked by instability, as over 1.5 million propertyless Greek refugees from Turkey had to be integrated into Greek society. <a href="/wiki/Cappadocian_Greeks" title="Cappadocian Greeks">Cappadocian Greeks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pontian_Greeks" class="mw-redirect" title="Pontian Greeks">Pontian Greeks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Antiochian_Greeks" class="mw-redirect" title="Antiochian Greeks">non-Greek followers of Greek Orthodoxy</a> were all subject to the exchange as well. Some of the refugees could not speak the language and were from what had been unfamiliar environments to mainland Greeks, such as in the case of the Cappadocians and non-Greeks. The refugees also made a dramatic post-war population boost, as the number of refugees was more than a quarter of Greece's prior population.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[125]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following the catastrophic events in Asia Minor, the monarchy was abolished <a href="/wiki/Greek_republic_referendum,_1924" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek republic referendum, 1924">via a referendum</a> in 1924 and the <a href="/wiki/Second_Hellenic_Republic" title="Second Hellenic Republic">Second Hellenic Republic</a> was declared. In 1935, a royalist general-turned-politician <a href="/wiki/Georgios_Kondylis" title="Georgios Kondylis">Georgios Kondylis</a> took power after a <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coup d'état</a> and abolished the republic, holding <a href="/wiki/Greek_monarchy_referendum,_1935" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek monarchy referendum, 1935">a rigged referendum</a>, after which <a href="/wiki/George_II_of_Greece" title="George II of Greece">King George II</a> returned to Greece and was restored to the throne. </p> 
      <h4><span id="Dictatorship.2C_World_War_II.2C_and_reconstruction"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Dictatorship,_World_War_II,_and_reconstruction">Dictatorship, World War II, and reconstruction</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/4th_of_August_Regime" title="4th of August Regime">4th of August Regime</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balkans_campaign_(World_War_II)" title="Balkans campaign (World War II)">Balkans campaign</a>, <a href="/wiki/Axis_occupation_of_Greece" title="Axis occupation of Greece">Axis occupation of Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_State_(1941%E2%80%931944)" title="Hellenic State (1941–1944)">Hellenic State</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greek_Civil_War" title="Greek Civil War">Greek Civil War</a>
      </div> 
      <p>An agreement between Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Ioannis_Metaxas" title="Ioannis Metaxas">Ioannis Metaxas</a> and the head of state <a href="/wiki/George_II_of_Greece" title="George II of Greece">George II</a> followed in 1936, which installed Metaxas as the head of a dictatorial regime known as the <a href="/wiki/4th_of_August_Regime" title="4th of August Regime">4th of August Regime</a>, inaugurating a period of authoritarian rule that would last, with short breaks, until 1974.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[126]</a></sup> Although a dictatorship, Greece remained on good terms with Britain and was not allied with the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Triple_Occupation_of_Greece.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Triple_Occupation_of_Greece.png/260px-Triple_Occupation_of_Greece.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="265" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Triple_Occupation_of_Greece.png/390px-Triple_Occupation_of_Greece.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Triple_Occupation_of_Greece.png/520px-Triple_Occupation_of_Greece.png 2x" data-file-width="899" data-file-height="917"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Triple_Occupation_of_Greece.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Axis_occupation_of_Greece" title="Axis occupation of Greece">Axis occupation of Greece</a>. Blue indicates the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italian</a>, red the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">German</a> and green the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Independent_Bulgaria" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Independent Bulgaria">Bulgarian</a>.
         <br>(in dark blue the Dodecanese, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Islands_of_the_Aegean" title="Italian Islands of the Aegean">Italian possession</a> since 1912)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p> On 28 October 1940, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Fascist Italy</a> demanded the surrender of Greece, but the Greek administration refused, and, in the following <a href="/wiki/Greco-Italian_War" title="Greco-Italian War">Greco-Italian War</a>, Greece repelled Italian forces into Albania, giving the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> their first victory over Axis forces on land. The Greek struggle and victory against the Italians received exuberant praise at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-youtube.com_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-youtube.com-131">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fafalios_and_Hadjipateras,_p._157_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fafalios_and_Hadjipateras,_p._157-132">[128]</a></sup> Most prominent is the quote attributed to <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>: "Hence we will not say that Greeks fight like heroes, but we will say that heroes fight like Greeks."<sup id="cite_ref-youtube.com_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-youtube.com-131">[127]</a></sup> French general <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a> was among those who praised the fierceness of the Greek resistance. In an official notice released to coincide with the Greek national celebration of the Day of Independence, De Gaulle expressed his admiration for the Greek resistance:</p>
      <blockquote>
       <p>In the name of the captured yet still alive French people, France wants to send her greetings to the Greek people who are fighting for their freedom. The 25 March 1941 finds Greece in the peak of their heroic struggle and in the top of their glory. Since the Battle of Salamis, Greece had not achieved the greatness and the glory which today holds.<sup id="cite_ref-Fafalios_and_Hadjipateras,_p._157_132-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fafalios_and_Hadjipateras,_p._157-132">[128]</a></sup></p>
      </blockquote>
      <p> The country would eventually fall to urgently dispatched <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">German</a> forces during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Greece" title="Battle of Greece">Battle of Greece</a>, despite the fierce Greek resistance, particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Metaxas_Line" title="Battle of the Metaxas Line">Battle of the Metaxas Line</a>. <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> himself recognised the bravery and the courage of the <a href="/wiki/Greek_army" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek army">Greek army</a>, stating in his address to the Reichstag on 11 December 1941, that: "Historical justice obliges me to state that of the enemies who took up positions against us, the Greek soldier particularly fought with the highest courage. He capitulated only when further resistance had become impossible and useless."<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[129]</a></sup> </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BF%CE%B9_%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD_%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD_%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%AD%CF%81%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7_%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%80%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%82,_%CE%9F%CE%BA%CF%84%CF%8E%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%82_1944.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BF%CE%B9_%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD_%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD_%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%AD%CF%81%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7_%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%80%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%82%2C_%CE%9F%CE%BA%CF%84%CF%8E%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%82_1944.jpg/170px-%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BF%CE%B9_%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD_%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD_%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%AD%CF%81%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7_%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%80%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%82%2C_%CE%9F%CE%BA%CF%84%CF%8E%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%82_1944.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="178" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BF%CE%B9_%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD_%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD_%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%AD%CF%81%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7_%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%80%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%82%2C_%CE%9F%CE%BA%CF%84%CF%8E%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%82_1944.jpg/255px-%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BF%CE%B9_%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD_%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD_%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%AD%CF%81%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7_%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%80%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%82%2C_%CE%9F%CE%BA%CF%84%CF%8E%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%82_1944.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BF%CE%B9_%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD_%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD_%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%AD%CF%81%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7_%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%80%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%82%2C_%CE%9F%CE%BA%CF%84%CF%8E%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%82_1944.jpg/340px-%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BF%CE%B9_%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD_%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD_%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%AD%CF%81%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7_%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%80%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%82%2C_%CE%9F%CE%BA%CF%84%CF%8E%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%82_1944.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3492" data-file-height="3651"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%CE%91%CE%B8%CE%B7%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BF%CE%B9_%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD_%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD_%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%B8%CE%AD%CF%81%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7_%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%80%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%82,_%CE%9F%CE%BA%CF%84%CF%8E%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF%CF%82_1944.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>People in <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a> celebrate the liberation from the Axis powers, October 1944. Postwar Greece would soon experience a <a href="/wiki/Greek_civil_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek civil war">civil war</a> and political polarization.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Nazis proceeded to administer Athens and Thessaloniki, while other regions of the country were given to Nazi Germany's partners, Fascist Italy and Bulgaria. The occupation brought about terrible hardships for the Greek civilian population. Over 100,000 civilians died of starvation during the winter of 1941–1942, tens of thousands more died because of reprisals by Nazis and <a href="/wiki/Collaboration_with_the_Axis_Powers_during_World_War_II#Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Collaboration with the Axis Powers during World War II">collaborators</a>, the country's economy was ruined, and the great majority of <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Greece" title="History of the Jews in Greece">Greek Jews</a> (tens of thousands) were deported and murdered in Nazi concentration camps.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mazower_2001,_p._155_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mazower_2001,_p._155-135">[131]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Greek_Resistance" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Resistance">Greek Resistance</a>, one of the most effective resistance movements in Europe, fought vehemently against the Nazis and their collaborators. The German occupiers committed <a href="/wiki/German_war_crimes#Greece" title="German war crimes">numerous atrocities, mass executions, and wholesale slaughter of civilians and destruction of towns and villages</a> in reprisals. In the course of the concerted anti-guerrilla campaign, hundreds of villages were systematically torched and almost 1 million Greeks left homeless.<sup id="cite_ref-Mazower_2001,_p._155_135-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mazower_2001,_p._155-135">[131]</a></sup> In total, the Germans executed some 21,000 Greeks, the Bulgarians 40,000, and the Italians 9,000.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[132]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (October 2019)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Following liberation and the Allied victory over the Axis, Greece annexed the <a href="/wiki/Dodecanese_Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Dodecanese Islands">Dodecanese Islands</a> from Italy and regained <a href="/wiki/Western_Thrace" title="Western Thrace">Western Thrace</a> from Bulgaria. The country almost immediately descended into <a href="/wiki/Greek_Civil_War" title="Greek Civil War">a bloody civil war</a> between <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communist</a> forces and the anti-communist Greek government, which lasted until 1949 with the latter's victory. The conflict, considered one of the earliest struggles of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Noam&amp;Chomsky_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Noam&amp;Chomsky-137">[133]</a></sup> resulted in further economic devastation, mass population displacement and severe political polarisation for the next thirty years.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[134]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although the post-war decades were characterised by social strife and widespread marginalisation of the left in political and social spheres, Greece nonetheless experienced <a href="/wiki/Greek_economic_miracle" title="Greek economic miracle">rapid economic growth</a> and recovery, propelled in part by the U.S.-administered <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[135]</a></sup> In 1952, Greece joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, reinforcing its membership in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Bloc" title="Western Bloc">Western Bloc</a> of the Cold War. </p> 
      <h4><span id="Military_regime_.281967.E2.80.9374.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_regime_(1967–74)">Military regime (1967–74)</span></h4> 
      <p>King <a href="/wiki/Constantine_II_of_Greece" title="Constantine II of Greece">Constantine II</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Apostasia_of_1965" title="Apostasia of 1965">dismissal</a> of <a href="/wiki/George_Papandreou_(senior)" class="mw-redirect" title="George Papandreou (senior)">George Papandreou</a>'s centrist government in July 1965 prompted a prolonged period of political turbulence, which culminated in a coup d'état on 21 April 1967 by the <a href="/wiki/Greek_military_junta_of_1967%E2%80%931974" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek military junta of 1967–1974">Regime of the Colonels</a>. Under the junta, civil rights were suspended, political repression was intensified, and human rights abuses, including state-sanctioned torture, were rampant. Economic growth remained rapid before plateauing in 1972. The brutal suppression of the <a href="/wiki/Athens_Polytechnic_uprising" title="Athens Polytechnic uprising">Athens Polytechnic uprising</a> on 17 November 1973 set in motion the events that caused the fall of the Papadopoulos regime, resulting in a counter-coup which overthrew <a href="/wiki/Georgios_Papadopoulos" title="Georgios Papadopoulos">Georgios Papadopoulos</a> and established brigadier <a href="/wiki/Dimitrios_Ioannidis" title="Dimitrios Ioannidis">Dimitrios Ioannidis</a> as the new junta strongman. On 20 July 1974, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_invasion_of_Cyprus" title="Turkish invasion of Cyprus">Turkey invaded the island of Cyprus</a> in response to a Greek-backed Cypriot coup, triggering a political crisis in Greece that led to the regime's collapse and the restoration of democracy through <a href="/wiki/Metapolitefsi" title="Metapolitefsi">Metapolitefsi</a>. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Third_Hellenic_Republic">Third Hellenic Republic</span></h4> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Greece&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Third_Hellenic_Republic" title="Third Hellenic Republic">Third Hellenic Republic</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Accession_of_Greece_to_the_European_Union.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e7/Accession_of_Greece_to_the_European_Union.png/220px-Accession_of_Greece_to_the_European_Union.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/e/e7/Accession_of_Greece_to_the_European_Union.png 1.5x" data-file-width="282" data-file-height="209"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Accession_of_Greece_to_the_European_Union.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Signing at <a href="/wiki/Zappeion" title="Zappeion">Zappeion</a> by <a href="/wiki/Constantine_Karamanlis" class="mw-redirect" title="Constantine Karamanlis">Constantine Karamanlis</a> of the documents for the accession of Greece to the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Communities</a> in 1979.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The former prime minister <a href="/wiki/Konstantinos_Karamanlis" title="Konstantinos Karamanlis">Konstantinos Karamanlis</a> was invited back from Paris where he had lived in self-exile since 1963, marking the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Metapolitefsi" title="Metapolitefsi">Metapolitefsi</a> era. The <a href="/wiki/Greek_legislative_election,_1974" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek legislative election, 1974">first multiparty elections</a> since 1964 were held on the first anniversary of the Polytechnic uprising. A democratic and republican <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Greece" title="Constitution of Greece">constitution</a> was promulgated on 11 June 1975 following a <a href="/wiki/Greek_republic_referendum,_1974" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek republic referendum, 1974">referendum</a> which chose to not restore the monarchy. </p>
      <p>Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Papandreou" title="Andreas Papandreou">Andreas Papandreou</a>, George Papandreou's son, founded the <a href="/wiki/Panhellenic_Socialist_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Panhellenic Socialist Movement">Panhellenic Socialist Movement</a> (PASOK) in response to Karamanlis's conservative <a href="/wiki/New_Democracy_(Greece)" title="New Democracy (Greece)">New Democracy</a> party, with the two political formations dominating in government over the next four decades. Greece rejoined NATO in 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-integrated1974_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-integrated1974-140">[e]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AdamHartDavis_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AdamHartDavis-141">[136]</a></sup> Greece became the tenth member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> (subsequently subsumed by the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>) on 1 January 1981, ushering in a period of sustained growth. Widespread investments in industrial enterprises and heavy infrastructure, as well as funds from the European Union and growing revenues from tourism, shipping, and a fast-growing service sector raised the country's standard of living to unprecedented levels. Traditionally strained <a href="/wiki/Greek%E2%80%93Turkish_relations" title="Greek–Turkish relations">relations with neighbouring Turkey</a> <a href="/wiki/Greek%E2%80%93Turkish_earthquake_diplomacy" title="Greek–Turkish earthquake diplomacy">improved when successive earthquakes hit both nations in 1999</a>, leading to the lifting of the Greek veto against <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">Turkey's bid</a> for EU membership. </p>
      <p>The country adopted the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> in 2001 and successfully hosted the <a href="/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics" title="2004 Summer Olympics">2004 Summer Olympic Games</a> in Athens.<sup id="cite_ref-europa.eu_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-europa.eu-142">[137]</a></sup> More recently, Greece has suffered greatly from the <a href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="Late-2000s recession">late-2000s recession</a> and has been central to the related <a href="/wiki/European_sovereign_debt_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="European sovereign debt crisis">European sovereign debt crisis</a>. Due to the adoption of the euro, when Greece experienced financial crisis, it could no longer <a href="/wiki/Devaluation" title="Devaluation">devalue</a> its currency to regain competitiveness. <a href="/wiki/Youth_unemployment" title="Youth unemployment">Youth unemployment</a> was especially high during the 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[138]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis" title="Greek government-debt crisis">Greek government-debt crisis</a>, and subsequent <a href="/wiki/Austerity" title="Austerity">austerity</a> policies, have resulted in protests and social strife. Left-wing <a href="/wiki/Syriza" title="Syriza">Syriza</a>, led by Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Tsipras" title="Alexis Tsipras">Alexis Tsipras</a>, governed Greece since 2015 until 2019. Syriza gained support by opposing the austerity policy that had affected Greeks since the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis" title="Greek government-debt crisis">Greek government-debt crisis</a>. However, prime minister Tsipras was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Kyriakos_Mitsotakis" title="Kyriakos Mitsotakis">Kyriakos Mitsotakis</a> after the landslide victory of centre-right New Democracy in the 2019 elections.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[139]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In March 2020, Greece's parliament elected a non-partisan candidate, <a href="/wiki/Ekaterini_Sakellaropoulou" class="mw-redirect" title="Ekaterini Sakellaropoulou">Ekaterini Sakellaropoulou</a>, as the first female <a href="/wiki/President_of_Greece" title="President of Greece">President of Greece</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[140]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_and_climate">Geography and climate</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Greece" title="Geography of Greece">Geography of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="noprint" style="padding:10px; border:1px #aaa solid; float:right; clear:right; margin-left:0.5em;"> 
       <div style="position: relative">
        <div class="center">
         <div class="floatnone">
          <a href="/wiki/File:000_Greqia_harta.PNG" class="image"><img alt="000 Greqia harta.PNG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/58/000_Greqia_harta.PNG" decoding="async" width="366" height="350" data-file-width="366" data-file-height="350"></a>
         </div>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute;left:18px;top:38px;">
         <small><b><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Albania.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Albania.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Flag_of_Albania.svg/25px-Flag_of_Albania.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="18" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Flag_of_Albania.svg/38px-Flag_of_Albania.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Flag_of_Albania.svg/50px-Flag_of_Albania.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="980" data-file-height="700"></a></b></small>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute;left:11px;top:52px;">
         <small><b><a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania"><span style="color: black;">Albania</span></a></b></small>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute;left:74px;top:10px;">
         <small><b><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_North_Macedonia.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of North Macedonia.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Flag_of_North_Macedonia.svg/25px-Flag_of_North_Macedonia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Flag_of_North_Macedonia.svg/38px-Flag_of_North_Macedonia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Flag_of_North_Macedonia.svg/50px-Flag_of_North_Macedonia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600"></a></b></small>
        </div> 
        <div style="position:absolute;left:50px;top:22px;">
         <small><b><a href="/wiki/North_Macedonia" title="North Macedonia"><span style="color: black;">North Macedonia</span></a></b></small>
