      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Shipwreck_Beach_-_Western_coast_of_Zakynthos,_Greece_(12).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Shipwreck_Beach_-_Western_coast_of_Zakynthos%2C_Greece_%2812%29.jpg/220px-Shipwreck_Beach_-_Western_coast_of_Zakynthos%2C_Greece_%2812%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Shipwreck_Beach_-_Western_coast_of_Zakynthos%2C_Greece_%2812%29.jpg/330px-Shipwreck_Beach_-_Western_coast_of_Zakynthos%2C_Greece_%2812%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Shipwreck_Beach_-_Western_coast_of_Zakynthos%2C_Greece_%2812%29.jpg/440px-Shipwreck_Beach_-_Western_coast_of_Zakynthos%2C_Greece_%2812%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3968" data-file-height="2976"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Shipwreck_Beach_-_Western_coast_of_Zakynthos,_Greece_(12).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Navagio" title="Navagio">Navagio</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/MV_Panagiotis" title="MV Panagiotis">shipwreck</a></i>) bay, <a href="/wiki/Zakynthos" title="Zakynthos">Zakynthos</a> island
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Located in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">Southern</a><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[141]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast Europe</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[142]</a></sup> Greece consists of a mountainous, peninsular mainland jutting out into the sea at the southern end of the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, ending at the <a href="/wiki/Peloponnese" title="Peloponnese">Peloponnese</a> peninsula (separated from the mainland by the <a href="/wiki/Corinth_Canal" title="Corinth Canal">canal</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Isthmus_of_Corinth" title="Isthmus of Corinth">Isthmus of Corinth</a>) and strategically located at the crossroads of <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[f]</a></sup> Due to its highly indented coastline and numerous islands, Greece has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_length_of_coastline" title="List of countries by length of coastline">11th longest coastline</a> in the world with 13,676&nbsp;km (8,498&nbsp;mi);<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[148]</a></sup> its land boundary is 1,160&nbsp;km (721&nbsp;mi). The country lies approximately between latitudes <a href="/wiki/35th_parallel_north" title="35th parallel north">34°</a> and <a href="/wiki/42nd_parallel_north" title="42nd parallel north">42° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/19th_meridian_east" title="19th meridian east">19°</a> and <a href="/wiki/30th_meridian_east" title="30th meridian east">30° E</a>, with the extreme points being:<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[149]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>North: <a href="/wiki/Ormenio" title="Ormenio">Ormenio</a> village</li> 
       <li>South: <a href="/wiki/Gavdos" title="Gavdos">Gavdos</a> island</li> 
       <li>East: <a href="/wiki/Strongyli_Megistis" title="Strongyli Megistis">Strongyli</a> (Kastelorizo, Megisti) island</li> 
       <li>West: <a href="/wiki/Othonoi" title="Othonoi">Othonoi</a> island</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>Eighty percent of Greece consists of mountains or hills, making the country one of the most mountainous in Europe. <a href="/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Mount Olympus</a>, the mythical abode of the <a href="/wiki/Twelve_Olympians" title="Twelve Olympians">Greek Gods</a>, culminates at Mytikas peak 2,918 metres (9,573&nbsp;ft),<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[150]</a></sup> the highest in the country. Western Greece contains a number of lakes and wetlands and is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Pindus" title="Pindus">Pindus</a> mountain range. The Pindus, a continuation of the <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">Dinaric Alps</a>, reaches a maximum elevation of 2,637&nbsp;m (8,652&nbsp;ft) at <a href="/wiki/Smolikas" title="Smolikas">Mt. Smolikas</a> (the second-highest in Greece) and historically has been a significant barrier to east–west travel. </p>
      <p>The Pindus range continues through the central Peloponnese, crosses the islands of <a href="/wiki/Kythera" class="mw-redirect" title="Kythera">Kythera</a> and Antikythera and finds its way into southwestern Aegean, in the island of Crete where it eventually ends. The islands of the Aegean are peaks of underwater mountains that once constituted an extension of the mainland. Pindus is characterised by its high, steep peaks, often dissected by numerous canyons and a variety of other karstic landscapes. The spectacular <a href="/wiki/Vikos_Gorge" title="Vikos Gorge">Vikos Gorge</a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/Vikos-Aoos_National_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Vikos-Aoos National Park">Vikos-Aoos National Park</a> in the Pindus range, is listed by the Guinness book of World Records as the deepest gorge in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[151]</a></sup> Another notable formation are the <a href="/wiki/Meteora" title="Meteora">Meteora</a> rock pillars, atop which have been built medieval Greek Orthodox monasteries. </p>
      <p>Northeastern Greece features another high-altitude mountain range, the <a href="/wiki/Rhodope_Mountains" title="Rhodope Mountains">Rhodope</a> range, spreading across the region of <a href="/wiki/East_Macedonia_and_Thrace" class="mw-redirect" title="East Macedonia and Thrace">East Macedonia and Thrace</a>; this area is covered with vast, thick, ancient forests, including the famous <a href="/wiki/Dadia_Forest" title="Dadia Forest">Dadia Forest</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Evros_(regional_unit)" title="Evros (regional unit)">Evros regional unit</a>, in the far northeast of the country. </p>
      <p>Extensive plains are primarily located in the regions of <a href="/wiki/Thessaly" title="Thessaly">Thessaly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Macedonia" title="Central Macedonia">Central Macedonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Thrace" title="Western Thrace">Thrace</a>. They constitute key economic regions as they are among the few arable places in the country. Rare marine species such as the pinniped seals and the <a href="/wiki/Loggerhead_sea_turtle" title="Loggerhead sea turtle">loggerhead sea turtle</a> live in the seas surrounding mainland Greece, while its dense forests are home to the endangered <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">brown bear</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">Eurasian lynx</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Roe_deer" title="Roe deer">roe deer</a> and the wild goat. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Islands">Islands</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Greece" title="List of islands of Greece">List of islands of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ionian_sea_islands,_pic6.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Ionian_sea_islands%2C_pic6.JPG/220px-Ionian_sea_islands%2C_pic6.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Ionian_sea_islands%2C_pic6.JPG/330px-Ionian_sea_islands%2C_pic6.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Ionian_sea_islands%2C_pic6.JPG/440px-Ionian_sea_islands%2C_pic6.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ionian_sea_islands,_pic6.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Greek mainland and several small islands seen from <a href="/wiki/Nydri" title="Nydri">Nydri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lefkada" title="Lefkada">Lefkada</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Greece features a <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Greece" title="List of islands of Greece">vast number of islands</a> - between 1,200 and 6,000, depending on the definition,<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[152]</a></sup> 227 of which are inhabited - and is considered a <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries#Non-contiguous" title="List of transcontinental countries">non-contiguous transcontinental country</a>. Crete is the largest and most populous island; <a href="/wiki/Euboea" title="Euboea">Euboea</a>, separated from the mainland by the 60&nbsp;m-wide <a href="/wiki/Euripus_Strait" title="Euripus Strait">Euripus Strait</a>, is the second largest, followed by <a href="/wiki/Lesbos" title="Lesbos">Lesbos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rhodes" title="Rhodes">Rhodes</a>. </p>
      <p>The Greek islands are traditionally grouped into the following clusters: the <a href="/wiki/Argo-Saronic_Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Argo-Saronic Islands">Argo-Saronic Islands</a> in the Saronic gulf near Athens, the Cyclades, a large but dense collection occupying the central part of the Aegean Sea, the <a href="/wiki/North_Aegean_islands" title="North Aegean islands">North Aegean islands</a>, a loose grouping off the west coast of Turkey, the Dodecanese, another loose collection in the southeast between Crete and Turkey, the <a href="/wiki/Sporades" title="Sporades">Sporades</a>, a small tight group off the coast of northeast Euboea, and the Ionian Islands, located to the west of the mainland in the Ionian Sea. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Greece" title="Climate of Greece">Climate of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Petra_Olympus.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Petra_Olympus.jpeg/220px-Petra_Olympus.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Petra_Olympus.jpeg/330px-Petra_Olympus.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Petra_Olympus.jpeg/440px-Petra_Olympus.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="3190" data-file-height="1795"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Petra_Olympus.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Mount Olympus</a> is the highest mountain in Greece and mythical abode of the <a href="/wiki/Gods_of_Olympus" class="mw-redirect" title="Gods of Olympus">Gods of Olympus</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Greece" title="Climate of Greece">climate of Greece</a> is primarily <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[153]</a></sup> featuring mild, wet winters and hot, dry summers.<sup id="cite_ref-Climate_Atlas_of_Greece_(Hellenic_National_Meteorological_Service)_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_Atlas_of_Greece_(Hellenic_National_Meteorological_Service)-160">[154]</a></sup> This climate occurs at all coastal locations, including Athens, the Cyclades, the Dodecanese, Crete, the Peloponnese, the Ionian Islands and parts of the Central Continental Greece region. The <a href="/wiki/Pindus" title="Pindus">Pindus</a> mountain range strongly affects the climate of the country, as areas to the west of the range are considerably wetter on average (due to greater exposure to south-westerly systems bringing in moisture) than the areas lying to the east of the range (due to a <a href="/wiki/Rain_shadow" title="Rain shadow">rain shadow</a> effect). </p>
      <p>The mountainous areas of Northwestern Greece (parts of <a href="/wiki/Epirus_(region)" title="Epirus (region)">Epirus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Greece" title="Central Greece">Central Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thessaly" title="Thessaly">Thessaly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Macedonia" title="Western Macedonia">Western Macedonia</a>) as well as in the mountainous central parts of Peloponnese&nbsp;– including parts of the regional units of <a href="/wiki/Achaea" title="Achaea">Achaea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arcadia_(regional_unit)" title="Arcadia (regional unit)">Arcadia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Laconia" title="Laconia">Laconia</a>&nbsp;– feature an <a href="/wiki/Alpine_climate" title="Alpine climate">Alpine climate</a> with heavy snowfalls. The inland parts of northern Greece, in Central Macedonia and <a href="/wiki/East_Macedonia_and_Thrace" class="mw-redirect" title="East Macedonia and Thrace">East Macedonia and Thrace</a> feature a <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate climate</a> with cold, damp winters and hot, dry summers with frequent thunderstorms. Snowfalls occur every year in the mountains and northern areas, and brief snowfalls are not unknown even in low-lying southern areas, such as Athens.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[155]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Greece" title="Wildlife of Greece">Wildlife of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">Phytogeographically</a>, Greece belongs to the <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">Boreal Kingdom</a> and is shared between the East Mediterranean province of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Region">Mediterranean Region</a> and the Illyrian province of the <a href="/wiki/Circumboreal_Region" title="Circumboreal Region">Circumboreal Region</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">World Wide Fund for Nature</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Environment_Agency" title="European Environment Agency">European Environment Agency</a>, the territory of Greece can be subdivided into six <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregions</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_deciduous_forests" title="Illyrian deciduous forests">Illyrian deciduous forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pindus_Mountains_mixed_forests" title="Pindus Mountains mixed forests">Pindus Mountains mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balkan_mixed_forests" title="Balkan mixed forests">Balkan mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhodope_montane_mixed_forests" class="mw-redirect" title="Rhodope montane mixed forests">Rhodope montane mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aegean_and_Western_Turkey_sclerophyllous_and_mixed_forests" title="Aegean and Western Turkey sclerophyllous and mixed forests">Aegean and Western Turkey sclerophyllous and mixed forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Crete_Mediterranean_forests" title="Crete Mediterranean forests">Crete Mediterranean forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-162">[156]</a></sup> It had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 6.6/10, ranking it 70th globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-163">[157]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Greece" title="Politics of Greece">Politics of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Hellenic_Parliament_from_high_above.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Hellenic_Parliament_from_high_above.jpg/260px-Hellenic_Parliament_from_high_above.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="174" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Hellenic_Parliament_from_high_above.jpg/390px-Hellenic_Parliament_from_high_above.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Hellenic_Parliament_from_high_above.jpg/520px-Hellenic_Parliament_from_high_above.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1071"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Hellenic_Parliament_from_high_above.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The building of the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Parliament" title="Hellenic Parliament">Hellenic Parliament</a> (<a href="/wiki/Old_Royal_Palace" title="Old Royal Palace">Old Royal Palace</a>) in central <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kapodistrias2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Kapodistrias2.jpg/170px-Kapodistrias2.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="251" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Kapodistrias2.jpg/255px-Kapodistrias2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Kapodistrias2.jpg/340px-Kapodistrias2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="350" data-file-height="516"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kapodistrias2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Count <a href="/wiki/Ioannis_Kapodistrias" title="Ioannis Kapodistrias">Ioannis Kapodistrias</a>, first governor, founder of the modern Greek State, and distinguished European diplomat
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Greece is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-con51,53_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con51,53-164">[158]</a></sup> The current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Greece" title="Constitution of Greece">Constitution</a> was drawn up and adopted by the Fifth Revisionary Parliament of the Hellenes and entered into force in 1975 after the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Greek_military_junta_of_1967%E2%80%931974" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek military junta of 1967–1974">military junta of 1967–1974</a>. It has been revised three times since, in <a href="/wiki/Greek_constitutional_amendment_of_1986" title="Greek constitutional amendment of 1986">1986</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_Constitutional_amendment_of_2001" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Constitutional amendment of 2001">2001</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_constitutional_amendment_of_2008" title="Greek constitutional amendment of 2008">2008</a> and 2019. The Constitution, which consists of 120 articles, provides for a <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a> into <a href="/wiki/Executive_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Executive branch">executive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative branch">legislative</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judicial_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial branch">judicial branches</a>, and grants extensive specific guarantees (further reinforced in 2001) of <a href="/wiki/Civil_liberties" title="Civil liberties">civil liberties</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Social rights">social rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDagtoglou199121_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDagtoglou199121-165">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVenizelos2002131–32,_165–72_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVenizelos2002131–32,_165–72-166">[160]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage" title="Women's suffrage">Women's suffrage</a> was guaranteed with an amendment to the 1952 Constitution. </p>
      <p>The nominal <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Greece" title="President of Greece">President of the Republic</a>, who is elected by the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Parliament" title="Hellenic Parliament">Parliament</a> for a five-year term.<sup id="cite_ref-con51,53_164-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con51,53-164">[158]</a></sup> According to the Constitution, executive power is exercised by the President and the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Greece" title="Cabinet of Greece">Government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-con51,53_164-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con51,53-164">[158]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Greek_Constitutional_amendment_of_1986" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Constitutional amendment of 1986">Constitutional amendment of 1986</a> curtailed the President's duties and powers to a significant extent, rendering the position largely ceremonial; most political power is thus vested in the Prime Minister, Greece's <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-M477-478_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-M477-478-167">[161]</a></sup> The position is filled by the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Prime Ministers of Greece">current leader</a> of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Greece" title="List of political parties in Greece">political party</a> that can obtain a vote of confidence by the Parliament. The President of the Republic formally appoints the Prime Minister and, on his recommendation, appoints and dismisses the other members of the Cabinet.<sup id="cite_ref-con51,53_164-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con51,53-164">[158]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Legislative powers are exercised by a 300-member elective <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral Parliament</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-con51,53_164-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con51,53-164">[158]</a></sup> Statutes passed by the Parliament are promulgated by the President of the Republic.<sup id="cite_ref-con51,53_164-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con51,53-164">[158]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Greece#Election_of_the_legislature" title="Elections in Greece">Parliamentary elections</a> are held every four years, but the President of the Republic is obliged to dissolve the Parliament earlier on the proposal of the Cabinet, in view of dealing with a national issue of exceptional importance.<sup id="cite_ref-con51,53_164-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con51,53-164">[158]</a></sup> The President is also obliged to dissolve the Parliament earlier, if the opposition manages to pass a <a href="/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence" title="Motion of no confidence">motion of no confidence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-con51,53_164-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-con51,53-164">[158]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Voting_age" title="Voting age">voting age</a> is 17.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[162]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a 2016 report by the OECD, Greeks display a moderate level of civic participation compared to most other developed countries; voter turnout was 64 percent during recent elections, lower than the OECD average of 69 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[163]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_parties">Political parties</span></h3> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Greece&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_parties_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Political parties of Greece">Political parties of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:AAA_2108_(45718115542)_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/AAA_2108_%2845718115542%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-AAA_2108_%2845718115542%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="229" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/AAA_2108_%2845718115542%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-AAA_2108_%2845718115542%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/AAA_2108_%2845718115542%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-AAA_2108_%2845718115542%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="863" data-file-height="1163"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:AAA_2108_(45718115542)_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kyriakos_Mitsotakis" title="Kyriakos Mitsotakis">Kyriakos Mitsotakis</a>, Prime Minister since 2019
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since the restoration of democracy, the Greek party system was dominated by the liberal-conservative <a href="/wiki/New_Democracy_(Greece)" title="New Democracy (Greece)">New Democracy</a> (ND) and the social-democratic <a href="/wiki/PASOK" title="PASOK">Panhellenic Socialist Movement</a> (PASOK).<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[g]</a></sup> Other parties represented in the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Parliament" title="Hellenic Parliament">Hellenic Parliament</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Syriza" title="Syriza">Coalition of the Radical Left</a> (SYRIZA), the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Greece" title="Communist Party of Greece">Communist Party of Greece</a> (KKE), <a href="/wiki/Greek_Solution" title="Greek Solution">Greek Solution</a> and <a href="/wiki/MeRA25" title="MeRA25">MeRA25</a>. </p>
      <p>PASOK and New Democracy largely alternated in power until the outbreak of the <a href="/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis" title="Greek government-debt crisis">government-debt crisis</a> in 2009. From that time, the two major parties, New Democracy and PASOK, experienced a sharp decline in popularity.<sup id="cite_ref-Political_Climate_and_Governance_December_2011_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Political_Climate_and_Governance_December_2011-171">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Political_Climate_and_Governance_January_2012_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Political_Climate_and_Governance_January_2012-172">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Panhellenic_Research_for_ET3_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Panhellenic_Research_for_ET3-173">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Research_from_Pulse_RC_for_Pontiki_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Research_from_Pulse_RC_for_Pontiki-174">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Varometro_Feb_2011_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Varometro_Feb_2011-175">[168]</a></sup> In November 2011, the two major parties joined the smaller <a href="/wiki/Popular_Orthodox_Rally" title="Popular Orthodox Rally">Popular Orthodox Rally</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Grand_coalition" title="Grand coalition">grand coalition</a>, pledging their parliamentary support for a <a href="/wiki/Government_of_national_unity" class="mw-redirect" title="Government of national unity">government of national unity</a> headed by former <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> vice-president <a href="/wiki/Lucas_Papademos" title="Lucas Papademos">Lucas Papademos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[169]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Panos_Kammenos" title="Panos Kammenos">Panos Kammenos</a> voted against this government and he split off from ND forming the <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_populism" title="Right-wing populism">right-wing populist</a> <a href="/wiki/Independent_Greeks" title="Independent Greeks">Independent Greeks</a>. </p>
      <p>The coalition government led the country to the <a href="/wiki/Greek_legislative_election,_May_2012" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek legislative election, May 2012">parliamentary elections of May 2012</a>. The power of the traditional Greek political parties, <a href="/wiki/PASOK" title="PASOK">PASOK</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Democracy_(Greece)" title="New Democracy (Greece)">New Democracy</a>, declined from 43% to 13% and from 33% to 18%, respectively. The left-wing party of <a href="/wiki/SYRIZA" class="mw-redirect" title="SYRIZA">SYRIZA</a> became the second major party, with an increase from 4% to 16%. No party could form a sustainable government, which led to the <a href="/wiki/Greek_legislative_election,_June_2012" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek legislative election, June 2012">parliamentary elections of June 2012</a>. The result of the second elections was the formation of a coalition government composed of <a href="/wiki/New_Democracy_(Greece)" title="New Democracy (Greece)">New Democracy</a> (29%), <a href="/wiki/PASOK" title="PASOK">PASOK</a> (12%) and <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Left_(Greece)" title="Democratic Left (Greece)">Democratic Left</a> (6%) parties. </p>
      <p>SYRIZA has since overtaken PASOK as the main party of the centre-left .<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[170]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Tsipras" title="Alexis Tsipras">Alexis Tsipras</a> led SYRIZA to victory in the <a href="/wiki/Greek_legislative_election,_January_2015" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek legislative election, January 2015">general election</a> held on 25 January 2015, falling short of an outright majority in Parliament by just two seats.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[171]</a></sup> The following morning, Tsipras reached an agreement with <a href="/wiki/Independent_Greeks" title="Independent Greeks">Independent Greeks</a> party to form a coalition, and he was sworn in as Prime Minister of Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[172]</a></sup> Tsipras called snap elections in August 2015, resigning from his post, which led to a month-long caretaker administration headed by judge <a href="/wiki/Vassiliki_Thanou-Christophilou" title="Vassiliki Thanou-Christophilou">Vassiliki Thanou-Christophilou</a>, Greece's first female prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[173]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Greek_legislative_election,_September_2015" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek legislative election, September 2015">September 2015 general election</a>, Alexis Tsipras led SYRIZA to another victory, winning 145 out of 300 seats<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[174]</a></sup> and re-forming the coalition with the Independent Greeks.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[175]</a></sup> However, he was defeated in the <a href="/wiki/2019_Greek_legislative_election" title="2019 Greek legislative election">July 2019 general election</a> by <a href="/wiki/Kyriakos_Mitsotakis" title="Kyriakos Mitsotakis">Kyriakos Mitsotakis</a> who leads New Democracy.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[176]</a></sup> On 7 July 2019, Kyriakos Mitsotakis was sworn in as the new Prime Minister of Greece. He formed a centre-right government after the landslide victory of his New Democracy party.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[177]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Greece" title="Foreign relations of Greece">Foreign relations of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Foreign_relations_of_Greece.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Foreign_relations_of_Greece.svg/340px-Foreign_relations_of_Greece.svg.png" decoding="async" width="340" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Foreign_relations_of_Greece.svg/510px-Foreign_relations_of_Greece.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Foreign_relations_of_Greece.svg/680px-Foreign_relations_of_Greece.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="245"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Foreign_relations_of_Greece.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Representation through:<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[178]</a></sup>
         <br>
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#3771c8; color:white;border:1px solid darkgray;">&nbsp;</span> embassy
         <br>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#aaccff; color:black;border:1px solid darkgray;">&nbsp;</span> embassy in another country
         <br>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#37c837; color:black;border:1px solid darkgray;">&nbsp;</span> general consulate
         <br>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#cccccc; color:black;border:1px solid darkgray;">&nbsp;</span> no representation
         <br>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:black; color:white;border:1px solid darkgray;">&nbsp;</span> Greece
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Greece's foreign policy is conducted through the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Greece)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Greece)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a> and its head, the <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Foreign_Affairs_(Greece)" title="Minister for Foreign Affairs (Greece)">Minister for Foreign Affairs</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Nikos_Dendias" title="Nikos Dendias">Nikos Dendias</a>. Officially, the main aims of the Ministry are to represent Greece before other states and international organizations;<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_mission_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_mission-186">[179]</a></sup> safeguard the interests of the Greek state and of its citizens abroad;<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_mission_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_mission-186">[179]</a></sup> promote Greek culture;<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_mission_186-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_mission-186">[179]</a></sup> foster closer relations with the <a href="/wiki/Greek_diaspora" title="Greek diaspora">Greek diaspora</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_mission_186-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_mission-186">[179]</a></sup> and encourage international cooperation.<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_mission_186-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_mission-186">[179]</a></sup> The Ministry identifies two issues of particular importance to the Greek state: <a href="/wiki/Greek%E2%80%93Turkish_relations" title="Greek–Turkish relations">Turkish challenges to Greek sovereignty rights</a> in the Aegean Sea and corresponding airspace and the <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">Cyprus dispute</a> involving the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_military_forces_in_Northern_Cyprus" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkish military forces in Northern Cyprus">Turkish occupation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cyprus" title="Northern Cyprus">Northern Cyprus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_issues_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_issues-187">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There is a long-standing <a href="/wiki/Aegean_dispute" title="Aegean dispute">conflict between Turkey and Greece</a> over natural resources in the eastern Mediterranean. Turkey doesn't recognize a legal <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf" title="Continental shelf">continental shelf</a> and <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">exclusive economic zone</a> around the Greek islands.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[181]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Additionally, due to its political and geographical proximity to <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, the Middle East and <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a>, Greece is a country of significant geostrategic importance, which it has leveraged to develop a regional policy to help promote peace and stability in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MFA_regional_policy_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MFA_regional_policy-189">[182]</a></sup> This has accorded the country <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> status in global affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-Thanos-Veremēs_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thanos-Veremēs-190">[183]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Greece is a member of numerous international organizations, including the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">Union for the Mediterranean</a>, the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="North Atlantic Treaty Organization">North Atlantic Treaty Organization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_francophonie" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation internationale de la francophonie">Organisation internationale de la francophonie</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, of which it is a founding member. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_justice">Law and justice</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial system of Greece">Judicial system of Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Law enforcement in Greece">Law enforcement in Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial system of Greece">Judiciary</a> is independent of the executive and the legislature and comprises three Supreme Courts: the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_(Greece)" class="mw-redirect" title="Court of Cassation (Greece)">Court of Cassation</a> (Άρειος Πάγος), the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_State_(Greece)" title="Council of State (Greece)">Council of State</a> (Συμβούλιο της Επικρατείας) and the <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Accounts_(Greece)" class="mw-redirect" title="Chamber of Accounts (Greece)">Court of Auditors</a> (Ελεγκτικό Συνέδριο). The Judiciary system is also composed of civil courts, which judge civil and penal cases and administrative courts, which judge disputes between the citizens and the Greek administrative authorities. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Police" title="Hellenic Police">Hellenic Police</a> (<a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">Ελληνική Αστυνομία</span>) is the national <a href="/wiki/Police" title="Police">police</a> force of Greece. It is a very large agency with its responsibilities ranging from <a href="/wiki/Road_traffic_control" title="Road traffic control">road traffic control</a> to <a href="/wiki/Counter-terrorism" title="Counter-terrorism">counter-terrorism</a>. It was established in 1984 under Law 1481/1-10-1984 (Government Gazette 152 A) as the result of the fusion of the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Gendarmerie" title="Hellenic Gendarmerie">Gendarmerie</a> (Χωροφυλακή, <i>Chorofylaki</i>) and the <a href="/wiki/Cities_Police" title="Cities Police">Cities Police</a> (Αστυνομία Πόλεων, <i>Astynomia Poleon</i>) forces.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[184]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">

        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:187px;max-width:187px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:HAF_F-16D_Falcon.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/HAF_F-16D_Falcon.jpg/185px-HAF_F-16D_Falcon.jpg" decoding="async" width="185" height="124" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/HAF_F-16D_Falcon.jpg/278px-HAF_F-16D_Falcon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/HAF_F-16D_Falcon.jpg/370px-HAF_F-16D_Falcon.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4256" data-file-height="2848"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">

          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:167px;max-width:167px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Hellenic_Army_-_LEO2A6HEL_-_7231.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Hellenic_Army_-_LEO2A6HEL_-_7231.jpg/165px-Hellenic_Army_-_LEO2A6HEL_-_7231.jpg" decoding="async" width="165" height="124" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Hellenic_Army_-_LEO2A6HEL_-_7231.jpg/248px-Hellenic_Army_-_LEO2A6HEL_-_7231.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Hellenic_Army_-_LEO2A6HEL_-_7231.jpg/330px-Hellenic_Army_-_LEO2A6HEL_-_7231.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2304" data-file-height="1728"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A <a href="/wiki/Leopard_2" title="Leopard 2">Leopard 2</a>A6 HEL of the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Army" title="Hellenic Army">Hellenic Army</a> on parade in Athens
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Hellenic Armed Forces are overseen by the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_National_Defense_General_Staff" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenic National Defense General Staff">Hellenic National Defense General Staff</a> (Greek: Γενικό Επιτελείο Εθνικής Άμυνας&nbsp;– ΓΕΕΘΑ), with civilian authority vested in the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defence_(Greece)" title="Ministry of National Defence (Greece)">Ministry of National Defence</a>. It consists of three branches: </p> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Army" title="Hellenic Army">Hellenic Army</a> (Ellinikos Stratos, ES)</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Navy" title="Hellenic Navy">Hellenic Navy</a> (Elliniko Polemiko Navtiko, EPN)</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Air_Force" title="Hellenic Air Force">Hellenic Air Force</a> (Elliniki Polemiki Aeroporia, EPA)</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>Moreover, Greece maintains the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Coast_Guard" title="Hellenic Coast Guard">Hellenic Coast Guard</a> for law enforcement at sea, search and rescue, and port operations. Though it can support the navy during wartime, it resides under the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Shipping_(Greece)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Shipping (Greece)">Ministry of Shipping</a>. </p>
      <p>Greek military personnel total 367,450, of whom 142,950 are active and 220,500 are reserve. Greece <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">ranks 15th in the world</a> in the number of citizens serving in the armed forces. <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Greece" title="Conscription in Greece">Mandatory military service</a> is nine months for the Army and one year for the Navy and Air Force.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[185]</a></sup> Additionally, Greek males between the ages of 18 and 60 who live in strategically sensitive areas may be required to serve part-time in the National Guard. </p>
      <p>As a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the Greek military participates in exercises and deployments under the auspices of the alliance, although its involvement in NATO missions is minimal.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[186]</a></sup> Greece spends over US$7 billion annually on its military, or 2.3 percent of GDP, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">24th-highest in the world</a> in absolute terms, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure_per_capita" title="List of countries by military expenditure per capita">seventh-highest</a> on a per capita basis, and the second-highest in NATO after the United States. Moreover, Greece is one of only five NATO countries to meet or surpass the minimum defence spending target of 2 percent of GDP. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Greece" title="Administrative divisions of Greece">Administrative divisions of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Since the <a href="/wiki/Kallikratis_programme" class="mw-redirect" title="Kallikratis programme">Kallikratis programme</a> reform entered into effect on 1 January 2011, Greece has consisted of thirteen <a href="/wiki/Modern_regions_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern regions of Greece">regions</a> subdivided into a total of 325 <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Municipalities of Greece">municipalities</a>. The 54 old <a href="/wiki/Prefectures_of_Greece" title="Prefectures of Greece">prefectures and prefecture-level administrations</a> have been largely retained as <i><a href="/wiki/Regional_units_of_Greece" title="Regional units of Greece">sub-units</a></i> of the regions. Seven <a href="/wiki/Decentralized_administrations_of_Greece" title="Decentralized administrations of Greece">decentralised administrations</a> group one to three regions for administrative purposes on a regional basis. There is also one <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous area">autonomous area</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Athos" title="Mount Athos">Mount Athos</a> (<a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">Agio Oros</span>, "Holy Mountain"), which borders the region of <a href="/wiki/Central_Macedonia" title="Central Macedonia">Central Macedonia</a>. </p> 
      <table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr style="font-size:100%; text-align:center;"> 
         <th>Map</th> 
         <th>No.</th>

         <th>Capital</th> 
         <th>Area (km<sup>2</sup>)</th> 
         <th>Area (sq. mi.)</th> 
         <th>Population<sup id="cite_ref-2011censusNSS_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011censusNSS-194">[187]</a></sup></th>

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td rowspan="15">
          <div class="center">
           <div class="floatnone">
            <a href="/wiki/File:Peripheries_of_Greece_numbered.svg" class="image"><img alt="Peripheries of Greece numbered.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Peripheries_of_Greece_numbered.svg/400px-Peripheries_of_Greece_numbered.svg.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="346" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Peripheries_of_Greece_numbered.svg/600px-Peripheries_of_Greece_numbered.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Peripheries_of_Greece_numbered.svg/800px-Peripheries_of_Greece_numbered.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="8460" data-file-height="7315"></a>
           </div>
          </div></td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;">1</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Attica_(region)" title="Attica (region)">Attica</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right">3,808.10</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right">1,470.32</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right">3,828,434</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right">€83.469 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;">2</td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Central_Greece_(region)" title="Central Greece (region)">Central Greece</a></td>

         <td style="text-align:right">1,830</td>
