       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Greece" title="Economy of Greece">Economy of Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Greek_subdivisions_by_GDP" title="List of Greek subdivisions by GDP">List of Greek subdivisions by GDP</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Introduction">Introduction</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Greece_Export_Treemap.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Greece_Export_Treemap.jpg/220px-Greece_Export_Treemap.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="172" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Greece_Export_Treemap.jpg/330px-Greece_Export_Treemap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Greece_Export_Treemap.jpg/440px-Greece_Export_Treemap.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2668" data-file-height="2086"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Greece_Export_Treemap.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Graphical depiction of Greece's product exports in 2012 in 28 color-coded categories
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> statistics for the year 2013, the economy of Greece is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">43rd</a> largest by <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal</a> <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> at $242 billion<sup id="cite_ref-World_Bank_GDP_(nominal)_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_GDP_(nominal)-196">[189]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">53nd</a> largest by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP) at $284 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-World_Bank_GDP_(PPP)_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_GDP_(PPP)-197">[190]</a></sup> Additionally, Greece is the 15th largest economy in the 27-member <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_GDP_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_GDP-198">[191]</a></sup> In terms of <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_income" title="Per capita income">per capita income</a>, Greece is ranked <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">41th</a> or <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">47th</a> in the world at $18,168 and $29,045 for nominal GDP and PPP respectively. The Greek economy is classified as advanced<sup id="cite_ref-Advanced_economies_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Advanced_economies-199">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[193]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-High_income_economies_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-High_income_economies-202">[195]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[196]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/High_income_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="High income economy">high-income</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[197]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-High_income_economies_202-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-High_income_economies-202">[195]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Exports-2018.png" class="image"><img alt="Graphical depiction of Greece's product exports in percent for 2018." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Exports-2018.png/220px-Exports-2018.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="95" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Exports-2018.png/330px-Exports-2018.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Exports-2018.png/440px-Exports-2018.png 2x" data-file-width="1450" data-file-height="629"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Exports-2018.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Graphical depiction of Greece's product exports (%) in 2018
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Greece is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> with a high standard of living and a high ranking in the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[200]</a></sup> Its economy mainly comprises the <a href="/wiki/Service_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Service sector">service sector</a> (85.0%) and <a href="/wiki/Industrial_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrial sector">industry</a> (12.0%), while <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a> makes up 3.0% of the national economic output.<sup id="cite_ref-GDP_by_sector_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GDP_by_sector-208">[201]</a></sup> Important Greek industries include <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Greece" title="Tourism in Greece">tourism</a> (with 14.9 million<sup id="cite_ref-World_Tourism_Organization_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Tourism_Organization-209">[202]</a></sup> international tourists in 2009, it is ranked as the 7th most visited country in the European Union<sup id="cite_ref-World_Tourism_Organization_209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Tourism_Organization-209">[202]</a></sup> and 16th in the world<sup id="cite_ref-World_Tourism_Organization_209-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Tourism_Organization-209">[202]</a></sup> by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_World_Tourism_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations World Tourism Organization">United Nations World Tourism Organization</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Greek_Merchant_Navy" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Merchant Navy">merchant shipping</a> (at 16.2%<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Shipping_report_2011_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Shipping_report_2011-210">[203]</a></sup> of the world's total capacity, the Greek merchant marine is the largest in the world<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Shipping_report_2011_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Shipping_report_2011-210">[203]</a></sup>), while the country is also a considerable agricultural producer (including fisheries) within the union. </p>
      <p>Greek <a href="/wiki/Unemployment" title="Unemployment">unemployment</a> stood at 21.7% in April 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[204]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Youth_unemployment" title="Youth unemployment">youth unemployment</a> rate (42.3% in March 2018) is extremely high compared to EU standards.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[205]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With an economy larger than all the other Balkan economies combined, Greece is the largest economy in the Balkans,<sup id="cite_ref-BalkanInsight_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BalkanInsight-213">[206]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Keridis_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Keridis-214">[207]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nicholas_Economides_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nicholas_Economides-215">[208]</a></sup> and an important regional investor.<sup id="cite_ref-BalkanInsight_213-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BalkanInsight-213">[206]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Keridis_214-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Keridis-214">[207]</a></sup> Greece is the number-two foreign investor of capital in Albania, the number-three foreign investor in Bulgaria, at the top-three of foreign investors in Romania and Serbia and the most important trading partner and largest foreign investor of North Macedonia. Greek banks open a new branch somewhere in the Balkans on an almost weekly basis.<sup id="cite_ref-Bell2002_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bell2002-216">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AydinIfantis2004_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AydinIfantis2004-217">[210]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Thompson2012_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thompson2012-218">[211]</a></sup> The Greek telecommunications company <a href="/wiki/OTE" title="OTE">OTE</a> has become a strong investor in Yugoslavia and other Balkan countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Bell2002_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bell2002-216">[209]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Greece was a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD) and the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation</a> (BSEC). In 1979 the accession of the country in the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Market_(European_Union)" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal Market (European Union)">single market</a> was signed, and the process was completed in 1982. Greece was accepted into the <a href="/wiki/Economic_and_Monetary_Union_of_the_European_Union" title="Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union">Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union</a> on 19 June 2000, and in January 2001 adopted the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">Euro</a> as its currency, replacing the <a href="/wiki/Greek_drachma" title="Greek drachma">Greek drachma</a> at an exchange rate of 340.75 drachma to the Euro.<sup id="cite_ref-Drachma_exchange_rate_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Drachma_exchange_rate-219">[212]</a></sup> Greece is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, and is ranked 24th on the KOF <a href="/wiki/Globalization_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="Globalization Index">Globalization Index</a> for 2013. </p> 
      <h3><span id="Debt_crisis_.282010.E2.80.932018.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Debt_crisis_(2010–2018)">Debt crisis (2010–2018)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis" title="Greek government-debt crisis">Greek government-debt crisis</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Greek_debt_and_EU_average_since_1977.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greek_debt_and_EU_average_since_1977.png/300px-Greek_debt_and_EU_average_since_1977.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="297" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greek_debt_and_EU_average_since_1977.png/450px-Greek_debt_and_EU_average_since_1977.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greek_debt_and_EU_average_since_1977.png/600px-Greek_debt_and_EU_average_since_1977.png 2x" data-file-width="689" data-file-height="681"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Greek_debt_and_EU_average_since_1977.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Greece's debt percentage since 1977, compared to the average of the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Greek economy had fared well for much of the 20th century, with high growth rates and low public debt<sup id="cite_ref-Debt_Past_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_Past-220">[213]</a></sup>). Even until the eve of the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">Financial crisis of 2007–2008</a>, it featured high rates of growth, which, however, were coupled with high structural deficits, thus maintaining a (roughly unchanged throughout this period) public debt to GDP ratio of just over 100%.<sup id="cite_ref-Debt_Past_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_Past-220">[213]</a></sup> The Greek crisis was triggered by the turmoil of the 2007–2009 <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>, which led the budget deficits of several Western nations to reach or exceed 10% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-Debt_Past_220-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_Past-220">[213]</a></sup> In Greece's case, the high budget deficit (which, after several corrections and revisions, was revealed that it had been allowed to reach 10.2% and 15.1% of GDP in 2008 and 2009, respectively) was coupled with a high public debt to GDP ratio (relatively stable, at just over 100% until 2007 - as calculated after all corrections). Thus, the country appeared to lose control of its public debt to GDP ratio, which already reached 127% of GDP in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-Debt_2009_2017_Eurostat_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_2009_2017_Eurostat-221">[214]</a></sup> In addition, being a member of the Eurozone, the country had essentially no autonomous <a href="/wiki/Economic_and_Monetary_Union_of_the_European_Union#Monetary_policy_inflexibility" title="Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union">monetary policy flexibility</a>. Finally, there was an effect of controversies about Greek statistics (due to the aforementioned drastic budget deficit revisions which led to an increase in the calculated value of the Greek public debt by <a href="/wiki/Greek_financial_audits,_2009%E2%80%9310" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek financial audits, 2009–10">about 10%</a>, i.e., a public debt to GDP of about 100% until 2007), while there have been arguments about a possible effect of <a href="/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis#Criticism_of_the_role_of_news_media_and_stereotyping" title="Greek government-debt crisis">media reports</a>. Consequently, Greece was "punished" by the markets which increased borrowing rates, making it impossible for the country to finance its debt since early 2010. </p>
      <p>The above revisions were largely connected with the fact that in the years before the crisis <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a>, <a href="/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase" title="JPMorgan Chase">JPMorgan Chase</a>, and numerous other banks had developed financial products which enabled the governments of Greece, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, and many other <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">European</a> countries to hide their borrowing.<sup id="cite_ref-Europe_derivatives_1_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europe_derivatives_1-222">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Europe_derivatives_2_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europe_derivatives_2-223">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[217]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[218]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Italy_swaps_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Italy_swaps-227">[220]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FT_Italy_derivatives_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FT_Italy_derivatives-228">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rehn_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rehn-229">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Goldman_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goldman-230">[223]</a></sup> Dozens of similar agreements were concluded across Europe whereby banks supplied cash in advance in exchange for future payments by the governments involved; in turn, the liabilities of the involved countries were "kept off the books".<sup id="cite_ref-Goldman_230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goldman-230">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bloomberg_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bloomberg-232">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Telegraph_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Telegraph-233">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Guardian_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Guardian-234">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Der_Spiegel_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Der_Spiegel-235">[228]</a></sup> These conditions had enabled Greece as well as other European governments to spend beyond their means, while meeting the deficit targets set out in the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Der_Spiegel_235-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Der_Spiegel-235">[228]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Goldman_230-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goldman-230">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[229]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In May 2010, the Greece's deficit was again revised and estimated to be 13.6%<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[230]</a></sup> which was the second highest in the world relative to GDP, with <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> in first place at 15.7% and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> in third with 12.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[231]</a></sup> Public debt was forecast, according to some estimates, to hit 120% of GDP in the same year,<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[232]</a></sup> causing a crisis of confidence in Greece's ability pay back loans. </p>
      <p>To avert a <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_default" title="Sovereign default">sovereign default</a>, Greece, the other <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> members, and the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> agreed on a rescue package which involved giving Greece an immediate €<span class="nowrap">45 billion</span> in loans, with additional funds to follow, totaling €<span class="nowrap">110 billion</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[234]</a></sup> To secure the funding, Greece was required to adopt harsh <a href="/wiki/Austerity" title="Austerity">austerity measures</a> to bring its deficit under control.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[235]</a></sup> A second bail-out amounting to €<span class="nowrap">130 billion</span> ($<span class="nowrap">173 billion</span>) was agreed in 2012, subject to strict conditions, including financial reforms and further austerity measures.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCQ&amp;A_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCQ&amp;A-243">[236]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Debt_relief" title="Debt relief">debt haircut</a> was also agreed as part of the deal.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCQ&amp;A_243-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCQ&amp;A-243">[236]</a></sup> Greece achieved a primary government <a href="/wiki/Balanced_budget" title="Balanced budget">budget surplus</a> in 2013, while in April 2014, it returned to the global <a href="/wiki/Bond_market" title="Bond market">bond market</a>. Greece returned to growth after six years of economic decline in the second quarter of 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-Kathimerini_growth_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kathimerini_growth-244">[237]</a></sup> and was the Eurozone's fastest-growing economy in the third quarter.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[238]</a></sup> A third bailout was agreed in July 2015, after a confrontation with the newly elected government of <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Tsipras" title="Alexis Tsipras">Alexis Tsipras</a>. </p>
      <p>There was a 25% drop in Greece's GDP, connected with the bailout programmes.<sup id="cite_ref-Debt_Past_220-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_Past-220">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Tsipras_Bloomberg_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tsipras_Bloomberg-246">[239]</a></sup> This had a critical effect: the Debt-to-GDP ratio, the key factor defining the severity of the crisis, would jump from its 2009 level of 127% to about 170%, solely due to the shrinking economy.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In a 2013 report, the IMF admitted that it had underestimated the effects of so extensive tax hikes and budget cuts on the country's GDP and issued an informal apology.<sup id="cite_ref-IMF_Guardian_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF_Guardian-247">[240]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-IMF_Reuters_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF_Reuters-248">[241]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-IMF_Telegraph_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF_Telegraph-249">[242]</a></sup> The Greek programmes imposed a very rapid improvement in structural primary balance (at least two times faster than for other Eurozone bailed-out countries<sup id="cite_ref-Fiscal_adjustment_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fiscal_adjustment-250">[243]</a></sup>). The policies have been blamed for worsening the crisis,<sup id="cite_ref-IMF_Bloomberg_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF_Bloomberg-251">[244]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-IMF_WSJ_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF_WSJ-252">[245]</a></sup> while Greece's president, <a href="/wiki/Prokopis_Pavlopoulos" title="Prokopis Pavlopoulos">Prokopis Pavlopoulos</a>, stressed the creditors' share in responsibility for the depth of the crisis.<sup id="cite_ref-Pavlopoulos_Statement_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pavlopoulos_Statement-253">[246]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pavlopoulos_Moscovici_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pavlopoulos_Moscovici-254">[247]</a></sup> Greek Prime Minister, Alexis Tsipras, asserted that errors in the design of the first two programmes which led to a loss of 25% of the Greek economy due to the harsh imposition of excessive austerity.<sup id="cite_ref-Tsipras_Bloomberg_246-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tsipras_Bloomberg-246">[239]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between 2009 and 2017 the Greek government debt rose from €300 bn to €318 bn, i.e. by only about 6% (thanks, in part, to the 2012 debt restructuring);<sup id="cite_ref-Debt_2009_2017_Eurostat_221-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_2009_2017_Eurostat-221">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Debt_2017_Eurostat_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_2017_Eurostat-255">[248]</a></sup> however, during the same period, the critical debt-to-GDP ratio shot up from 127% to 179%<sup id="cite_ref-Debt_2009_2017_Eurostat_221-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_2009_2017_Eurostat-221">[214]</a></sup> basically due to the severe GDP drop <a href="/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis#Effect_of_applied_programmes_on_the_debt_crisis" title="Greek government-debt crisis">during the handling of the crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Debt_Past_220-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Debt_Past-220">[213]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Greece's bailouts successfully ended (as declared) on 20 August 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-Bailout_exit_Reuters_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bailout_exit_Reuters-256">[249]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Greece" title="Agriculture in Greece">Agriculture in Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Zante_currant_drying_in_Tsilivi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Zante_currant_drying_in_Tsilivi.jpg/220px-Zante_currant_drying_in_Tsilivi.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Zante_currant_drying_in_Tsilivi.jpg/330px-Zante_currant_drying_in_Tsilivi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Zante_currant_drying_in_Tsilivi.jpg/440px-Zante_currant_drying_in_Tsilivi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="681"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Zante_currant_drying_in_Tsilivi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Sun-drying of <a href="/wiki/Zante_currant" title="Zante currant">Zante currant</a> on <a href="/wiki/Zakynthos" title="Zakynthos">Zakynthos</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2010, Greece was the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>'s largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a> (183,800 tons) and <a href="/wiki/Pistachios" class="mw-redirect" title="Pistachios">pistachios</a> (8,000 tons)<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_agriculture_1_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat_agriculture_1-257">[250]</a></sup> and ranked second in the production of <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> (229,500 tons)<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_agriculture_1_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat_agriculture_1-257">[250]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">olives</a> (147,500 tons),<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_agriculture_2_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat_agriculture_2-258">[251]</a></sup> third in the production of <a href="/wiki/Common_fig" title="Common fig">figs</a> (11,000 tons),<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_agriculture_2_258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat_agriculture_2-258">[251]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Almond" title="Almond">almonds</a> (44,000 tons),<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_agriculture_2_258-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat_agriculture_2-258">[251]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">tomatoes</a> (1,400,000 tons),<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_agriculture_2_258-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat_agriculture_2-258">[251]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Watermelon" title="Watermelon">watermelons</a> (578,400 tons)<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_agriculture_2_258-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat_agriculture_2-258">[251]</a></sup> and fourth in the production of <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a> (22,000 tons).<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_agriculture_1_257-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat_agriculture_1-257">[250]</a></sup> Agriculture contributes 3.8% of the country's GDP and employs 12.4% of the country's labor force. </p>
      <p>Greece is a major beneficiary of the <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a> of the European Union. As a result of the country's entry to the European Community, much of its agricultural infrastructure has been upgraded and agricultural output increased. Between 2000 and 2007, <a href="/wiki/Organic_farming" title="Organic farming">organic farming</a> in Greece increased by 885%, the highest change percentage in the EU. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Greece" title="Energy in Greece">Energy in Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Greece_GHI_Solar-resource-map_GlobalSolarAtlas_World-Bank-Esmap-Solargis.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Greece_GHI_Solar-resource-map_GlobalSolarAtlas_World-Bank-Esmap-Solargis.png/200px-Greece_GHI_Solar-resource-map_GlobalSolarAtlas_World-Bank-Esmap-Solargis.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="224" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Greece_GHI_Solar-resource-map_GlobalSolarAtlas_World-Bank-Esmap-Solargis.png/300px-Greece_GHI_Solar-resource-map_GlobalSolarAtlas_World-Bank-Esmap-Solargis.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Greece_GHI_Solar-resource-map_GlobalSolarAtlas_World-Bank-Esmap-Solargis.png/400px-Greece_GHI_Solar-resource-map_GlobalSolarAtlas_World-Bank-Esmap-Solargis.png 2x" data-file-width="1842" data-file-height="2063"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:SolarGIS-Solar-map-Greece-en.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Solar-power generation potential in Greece
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Electricity production in Greece is dominated by the state-owned <a href="/wiki/Public_Power_Corporation_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Public Power Corporation of Greece">Public Power Corporation</a> (known mostly by its acronym ΔΕΗ, transliterated as DEI). In 2009 DEI supplied for 85.6% of all electric energy demand in Greece,<sup id="cite_ref-DEI_2010_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEI_2010-259">[252]</a></sup> while the number fell to 77.3% in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-DEI_2010_259-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEI_2010-259">[252]</a></sup> Almost half (48%) of DEI's power output is generated using <a href="/wiki/Lignite" title="Lignite">lignite</a>, a drop from the 51.6% in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-DEI_2010_259-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEI_2010-259">[252]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Twelve percent of Greece's electricity comes from hydroelectric power plants<sup id="cite_ref-Invest_in_Greece_energy_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Invest_in_Greece_energy-260">[253]</a></sup> and another 20% from <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Invest_in_Greece_energy_260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Invest_in_Greece_energy-260">[253]</a></sup> Between 2009 and 2010, independent companies' energy production increased by 56%,<sup id="cite_ref-DEI_2010_259-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEI_2010-259">[252]</a></sup> from 2,709 <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt_hour" class="mw-redirect" title="Kilowatt hour">Gigawatt hour</a> in 2009 to 4,232 GWh in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-DEI_2010_259-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DEI_2010-259">[252]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2012, renewable energy accounted for 13.8% of the country's total energy consumption,<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_renewable_energy_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_renewable_energy-261">[254]</a></sup> a rise from the 10.6% it accounted for in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_renewable_energy_261-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_renewable_energy-261">[254]</a></sup> a figure almost equal to the EU average of 14.1% in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_renewable_energy_261-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_renewable_energy-261">[254]</a></sup> 10% of the country's renewable energy comes from <a href="/wiki/Solar_power" title="Solar power">solar power</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Sustainable_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Sustainable-262">[255]</a></sup> while most comes from <a href="/wiki/Biomass" title="Biomass">biomass</a> and waste recycling.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Sustainable_262-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Sustainable-262">[255]</a></sup> In line with the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>'s Directive on Renewable Energy, Greece aims to get 18% of its energy from renewable sources by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-Directive_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Directive-263">[256]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2013, according to the independent power transmission operator in Greece (ΑΔΜΗΕ) more than 20% of the electricity in Greece has been produced from renewable energy sources and hydroelectric powerplants. This percentage in April reached 42%. Greece currently does not have any <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plants</a> in operation; however, in 2009 the <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Athens_(modern)" title="Academy of Athens (modern)">Academy of Athens</a> suggested that research in the possibility of Greek nuclear power plants begin.<sup id="cite_ref-Academy_of_Athens_nuclear_power_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Academy_of_Athens_nuclear_power-264">[257]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Maritime_industry">Maritime industry</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Greek_shipping" title="Greek shipping">Greek shipping</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_ports_in_Greece" title="List of ports in Greece">List of ports in Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Greece#Maritime_industry" title="Economy of Greece">Economy of Greece&nbsp;» Maritime industry</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Greek_tanker_ship.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Greek_tanker_ship.png/200px-Greek_tanker_ship.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="130" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Greek_tanker_ship.png/300px-Greek_tanker_ship.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Greek_tanker_ship.png/400px-Greek_tanker_ship.png 2x" data-file-width="1019" data-file-height="663"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Greek_tanker_ship.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Greek_Merchant_Navy" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Merchant Navy">Greek companies</a> control 16.2% of the world's total <a href="/wiki/Merchant_fleet" class="mw-redirect" title="Merchant fleet">merchant fleet</a><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> making it the largest in the world. They are ranked in the top 5 for all kinds of ships, including first for tankers and bulk carriers.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The shipping industry has been a key element of Greek economic activity since ancient times.<sup id="cite_ref-shipping_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shipping-265">[258]</a></sup> Shipping remains one of the country's most important industries, accounting for 4.5 percent of GDP, employing about 160,000 people (4 percent of the workforce), and representing a third of the trade deficit.<sup id="cite_ref-nbg_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nbg-266">[259]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a 2011 report by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_Trade_and_Development" title="United Nations Conference on Trade and Development">United Nations Conference on Trade and Development</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Greek_Merchant_Navy" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Merchant Navy">Greek Merchant Navy</a> is the largest in the world at 16.2 percent of total global capacity,<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Shipping_report_2011_210-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Shipping_report_2011-210">[203]</a></sup> up from 15.96 percent in 2010<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Shipping_report_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Shipping_report-267">[260]</a></sup> but below the peak of 18.2 percent in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Shipping_report_2_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Shipping_report_2-268">[261]</a></sup> The country's merchant fleet ranks first in total tonnage (202 million <a href="/wiki/Deadweight_tonnage" title="Deadweight tonnage">dwt</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Shipping_report_2011_210-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Shipping_report_2011-210">[203]</a></sup> fourth in total number of ships (at 3,150), first in both <a href="/wiki/Tanker_(ship)" title="Tanker (ship)">tankers</a> and dry <a href="/wiki/Bulk_carrier" title="Bulk carrier">bulk carriers</a>, fourth in the number of <a href="/wiki/Container_ship" title="Container ship">containers</a>, and fifth in other ships.<sup id="cite_ref-BTS_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BTS-269">[262]</a></sup> However, today's fleet roster is smaller than an all-time high of 5,000 ships in the late 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-shipping_265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shipping-265">[258]</a></sup> Additionally, the total number of ships flying a Greek flag (includes non-Greek fleets) is 1,517, or 5.3 percent of the world's dwt (ranked fifth globally).<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Shipping_report_267-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Shipping_report-267">[260]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the 1960s, the size of the Greek fleet nearly doubled, primarily through the investment undertaken by the shipping magnates, <a href="/wiki/Aristotle_Onassis" title="Aristotle Onassis">Aristotle Onassis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stavros_Niarchos" title="Stavros Niarchos">Stavros Niarchos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-slate_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slate-270">[263]</a></sup> The basis of the modern Greek maritime industry was formed after World War II when Greek shipping businessmen were able to amass surplus ships sold to them by the U.S. government through the Ship Sales Act of the 1940s.<sup id="cite_ref-slate_270-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slate-270">[263]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Greece has a significant shipbuilding and ship maintenance industry. The six shipyards around the port of Piraeus are among the largest in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[264]</a></sup> In recent years, Greece has also become a leader in the construction and maintenance of luxury yachts.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[265]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Greece" title="Tourism in Greece">Tourism in Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Blue-dome-Santorini.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0a/Blue-dome-Santorini.JPG/220px-Blue-dome-Santorini.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0a/Blue-dome-Santorini.JPG/330px-Blue-dome-Santorini.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0a/Blue-dome-Santorini.JPG/440px-Blue-dome-Santorini.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2872" data-file-height="1820"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Blue-dome-Santorini.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Santorini" title="Santorini">Santorini</a>, a popular tourist destination, is ranked as the world's top island in many travel magazines and sites.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[266]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[267]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Tourism has been a key element of the economic activity in the country and one of the country's most important sectors, contributing 20.6% of the gross domestic product as of 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[268]</a></sup> Greece welcomed over 28 million visitors in 2016,<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[269]</a></sup> which is an increase from the 26.5 million tourists it welcomed in 2015 and the 19.5 million in 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Tourism_table_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Tourism_table-277">[270]</a></sup> and the 17.7 million tourists in 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Tourism_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Tourism-278">[271]</a></sup> making Greece one of the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings#Europe" title="World Tourism rankings">most visited countries</a> in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> in the recent years. </p>
      <p>The vast majority of visitors in Greece in 2007 came from the European continent, numbering 12.7 million,<sup id="cite_ref-A2001_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A2001-279">[272]</a></sup> while the most visitors from a single nationality were those from the United Kingdom, (2.6 million), followed closely by those from Germany (2.3 million).<sup id="cite_ref-A2001_279-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A2001-279">[272]</a></sup> In 2010, the most visited <a href="/wiki/Modern_regions_of_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern regions of Greece">region</a> of Greece was that of <a href="/wiki/Central_Macedonia" title="Central Macedonia">Central Macedonia</a>, with 18% of the country's total tourist flow (amounting to 3.6 million tourists), followed by <a href="/wiki/Attica" title="Attica">Attica</a> with 2.6 million and the <a href="/wiki/Peloponnese" title="Peloponnese">Peloponnese</a> with 1.8 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Tourism_table_277-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Tourism_table-277">[270]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Northern_Greece" title="Northern Greece">Northern Greece</a> is the country's most-visited geographical region, with 6.5 million tourists, while Central Greece is second with 6.3 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Tourism_table_277-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Tourism_table-277">[270]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2010, <a href="/wiki/Lonely_Planet" title="Lonely Planet">Lonely Planet</a> ranked Greece's northern and second-largest city of <a href="/wiki/Thessaloniki" title="Thessaloniki">Thessaloniki</a> as the world's fifth-best party town worldwide, comparable to other cities such as <a href="/wiki/Dubai" title="Dubai">Dubai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Montreal" title="Montreal">Montreal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[273]</a></sup> In 2011, <a href="/wiki/Santorini" title="Santorini">Santorini</a> was voted as "The World's Best Island" in <i><a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure">Travel + Leisure</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Best_Islands_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Best_Islands-281">[274]</a></sup> Its neighboring island <a href="/wiki/Mykonos" title="Mykonos">Mykonos</a>, came in fifth in the European category.<sup id="cite_ref-Best_Islands_281-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Best_Islands-281">[274]</a></sup> There are 18 <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> in Greece,<sup id="cite_ref-Unesco_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unesco-282">[275]</a></sup> and Greece is ranked 16th in the world in terms of total sites. 14 further sites are on the tentative list, awaiting nomination.<sup id="cite_ref-Unesco_282-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unesco-282">[275]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1308px">
       <div class="thumbinner">
        <div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto">
         <a href="/wiki/File:Corfu_Town_R02.jpg" class="image" title="Panoramic view of the old Corfu City, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, as seen from the Old Fortress. The Bay of Garitsa is to the left and the port of Corfu is just visible on the top right. Spianada Square is in the foreground."><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Corfu_Town_R02.jpg/1300px-Corfu_Town_R02.jpg" decoding="async" width="1300" height="265" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Corfu_Town_R02.jpg/1950px-Corfu_Town_R02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Corfu_Town_R02.jpg/2600px-Corfu_Town_R02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="8999" data-file-height="1835"></a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Corfu_Town_R02.jpg" title="File:Corfu Town R02.jpg"> </a>
         </div>Panoramic view of the old <a href="/wiki/Corfu_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Corfu City">Corfu City</a>, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>, as seen from the <a href="/wiki/Old_Fortress,_Corfu" title="Old Fortress, Corfu">Old Fortress</a>. The Bay of Garitsa is to the left and the port of <a href="/wiki/Corfu" title="Corfu">Corfu</a> is just visible on the top right. <a href="/wiki/Spianada_Square" class="mw-redirect" title="Spianada Square">Spianada Square</a> is in the foreground.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <table class="box-Unreferenced_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Unreferenced" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">cite</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">sources</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Greece&amp;action=edit">improve this section</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">removed</a>.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Greece" title="Transport in Greece">Transport in Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Rio_-_Antirrio_Bridge_at_sunset.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/The_Rio_-_Antirrio_Bridge_at_sunset.jpg/220px-The_Rio_-_Antirrio_Bridge_at_sunset.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/The_Rio_-_Antirrio_Bridge_at_sunset.jpg/330px-The_Rio_-_Antirrio_Bridge_at_sunset.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/The_Rio_-_Antirrio_Bridge_at_sunset.jpg/440px-The_Rio_-_Antirrio_Bridge_at_sunset.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4496" data-file-height="2901"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Rio_-_Antirrio_Bridge_at_sunset.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Rio%E2%80%93Antirrio_bridge" class="mw-redirect" title="Rio–Antirrio bridge">Rio–Antirrio bridge</a> connects mainland Greece to the <a href="/wiki/Peloponnese" title="Peloponnese">Peloponnese</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since the 1980s, the road and rail network of Greece has been significantly modernised. Important works include the <a href="/wiki/Egnatia_Odos_(modern_road)" title="Egnatia Odos (modern road)">A2 (Egnatia Odos)</a> motorway, that connects northwestern Greece (<a href="/wiki/Igoumenitsa" title="Igoumenitsa">Igoumenitsa</a>) with northern Greece (Thessaloniki) and northeastern Greece (<a href="/wiki/Kipoi,_Evros" title="Kipoi, Evros">Kipoi</a>); the <a href="/wiki/Rio%E2%80%93Antirrio_bridge" class="mw-redirect" title="Rio–Antirrio bridge">Rio–Antirrio bridge</a>, the longest suspension cable bridge in Europe (2,250&nbsp;m (7,382&nbsp;ft) long), connecting the Peloponnese (<a href="/wiki/Rio,_Greece" title="Rio, Greece">Rio</a>, 7&nbsp;km (4&nbsp;mi) from <a href="/wiki/Patras" title="Patras">Patras</a>) with Aetolia-Akarnania (<a href="/wiki/Antirrio" title="Antirrio">Antirrio</a>) in western Greece. </p>
      <p>Also completed are the <a href="/wiki/Ionia_Odos" class="mw-redirect" title="Ionia Odos">A5 (Ionia Odos)</a> motorway that connects northwestern Greece (<a href="/wiki/Ioannina" title="Ioannina">Ioannina</a>) with western Greece (Antirrio); the last sections of the <a href="/wiki/Motorway_1_(Greece)" title="Motorway 1 (Greece)">A1 motorway</a>, connecting Athens to <a href="/wiki/Thessaloniki" title="Thessaloniki">Thessaloniki</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evzonoi" title="Evzonoi">Evzonoi</a> in northern Greece; as well as the <a href="/wiki/Motorway_8_(Greece)" title="Motorway 8 (Greece)">A8 motorway</a> (part of the <a href="/wiki/Olympia_Odos" title="Olympia Odos">Olympia Odos</a>) in Peloponnese, connecting Athens to Patras. The remaining section of Olympia Odos, connecting Patras with <a href="/wiki/Pyrgos,_Ilia" class="mw-redirect" title="Pyrgos, Ilia">Pyrgos</a>, is under planning. </p>
      <p>Other important projects that are currently underway, include the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Thessaloniki_Metro" title="Thessaloniki Metro">Thessaloniki Metro</a>. </p>
      <p>The Athens Metropolitan Area in particular is served by some of the most modern and efficient transport infrastructure in Europe, such as the <a href="/wiki/Athens_International_Airport" title="Athens International Airport">Athens International Airport</a>, the privately run <a href="/wiki/Attiki_Odos" title="Attiki Odos">A6 (Attiki Odos)</a> motorway network and the expanded <a href="/wiki/Athens_Metro" title="Athens Metro">Athens Metro</a> system. </p>
      <p>Most of the Greek islands and many main cities of Greece are connected by air mainly from the two major Greek airlines, <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Air" title="Olympic Air">Olympic Air</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Airlines" title="Aegean Airlines">Aegean Airlines</a>. Maritime connections have been improved with modern high-speed craft, including <a href="/wiki/Hydrofoils" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydrofoils">hydrofoils</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catamarans" class="mw-redirect" title="Catamarans">catamarans</a>. </p>
      <p>Railway connections play a somewhat lesser role in Greece than in many other European countries, but they too have also been expanded, with new suburban/<a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail" title="Commuter rail">commuter rail</a> connections, serviced by <a href="/wiki/Proastiakos" title="Proastiakos">Proastiakos</a> around Athens, towards its airport, <a href="/wiki/Kiato" title="Kiato">Kiato</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chalcis" title="Chalcis">Chalkida</a>; around Thessaloniki, towards the cities of <a href="/wiki/Larissa" title="Larissa">Larissa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edessa,_Greece" title="Edessa, Greece">Edessa</a>; and around Patras. A modern intercity rail connection between Athens and Thessaloniki has also been established, while an upgrade to double lines in many parts of the 2,500&nbsp;km (1,600&nbsp;mi) network is underway; along with a <a href="/wiki/P.A.Th.E./P." title="P.A.Th.E./P.">new double track, standard gauge</a> railway between <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patras" title="Patras">Patras</a> (replacing the old <a href="/wiki/Metre-gauge_railway" title="Metre-gauge railway">metre-gauge</a> <a href="/wiki/Piraeus%E2%80%93Patras_railway" title="Piraeus–Patras railway">Piraeus–Patras railway</a>) which is currently under construction and opening in stages.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[276]</a></sup> International railway lines connect Greek cities with the rest of Europe, the Balkans and Turkey. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunications">Telecommunications</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Greece" title="Telecommunications in Greece">Telecommunications in Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Modern digital information and communication networks reach all areas. There are over 35,000&nbsp;km (21,748&nbsp;mi) of fiber optics and an extensive open-wire network. Broadband internet availability is widespread in Greece: there were a total of 2,252,653 broadband connections as of early 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Greece&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, translating to 20% broadband penetration.<sup id="cite_ref-cnbc_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnbc-284">[277]</a></sup> According to 2017 data, around 82% of the general population used the internet regularly.<sup id="cite_ref-Kathimerini_article_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kathimerini_article-285">[278]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Internet_caf%C3%A9" title="Internet café">Internet cafés</a> that provide net access, office applications and multiplayer gaming are also a common sight in the country, while mobile internet on <a href="/wiki/3G" title="3G">3G</a> and <a href="/wiki/4G" title="4G">4G</a>- <a href="/wiki/LTE_(telecommunication)" title="LTE (telecommunication)">LTE</a> cellphone networks and <a href="/wiki/Wi-Fi" title="Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a> connections can be found almost everywhere.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[279]</a></sup> 3G/4G mobile internet usage has been on a sharp increase in recent years. Based on 2016 data 70% of Greek internet users have access via 3G/4G mobile.<sup id="cite_ref-Kathimerini_article_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kathimerini_article-285">[278]</a></sup> The United Nations International Telecommunication Union ranks Greece among the top 30 countries with a highly developed information and communications infrastructure.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[280]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Greece&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Greek_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Greek inventions and discoveries">List of Greek inventions and discoveries</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:NOESIS.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/NOESIS.jpg/180px-NOESIS.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/NOESIS.jpg/270px-NOESIS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/NOESIS.jpg/360px-NOESIS.jpg 2x" data-file-width="529" data-file-height="664"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:NOESIS.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Thessaloniki_Science_Center_and_Technology_Museum" title="Thessaloniki Science Center and Technology Museum">Thessaloniki Science Center and Technology Museum</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Gnpapanikolaou.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Gnpapanikolaou.jpg/180px-Gnpapanikolaou.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="251" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Gnpapanikolaou.jpg/270px-Gnpapanikolaou.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Gnpapanikolaou.jpg/360px-Gnpapanikolaou.jpg 2x" data-file-width="602" data-file-height="840"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Gnpapanikolaou.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Georgios_Papanikolaou" title="Georgios Papanikolaou">Georgios Papanikolaou</a>, a pioneer in <a href="/wiki/Cytopathology" title="Cytopathology">cytopathology</a> and early cancer detection
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The General Secretariat for Research and Technology of the Ministry of Development and Competitiveness is responsible for designing, implementing and supervising national research and technological policy. In 2017, spending on research and development (R&amp;D) reached an all-time high of €2 billion, equal to 1.14 percent of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[281]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although lower than the EU average of 1.93 percent, between 1990 and 1998, total R&amp;D expenditure in Greece enjoyed the third-highest increase in Europe, after <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> and Ireland. Because of its strategic location, qualified workforce, and political and economic stability, many multinational companies such as <a href="/wiki/Ericsson" title="Ericsson">Ericsson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siemens_AG" class="mw-redirect" title="Siemens AG">Siemens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Motorola" title="Motorola">Motorola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">Coca-Cola</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tesla,_Inc." title="Tesla, Inc.">Tesla</a> have their regional R&amp;D headquarters in Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[282]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Greece has several major technology parks with incubator facilities and has been a member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> (ESA) since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[283]</a></sup> Cooperation between ESA and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hellenic_National_Space_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hellenic National Space Committee (page does not exist)">Hellenic National Space Committee</a> began in 1994 with the signing of the first cooperation agreement. After applying for full membership in 2003, Greece became the ESA's sixteenth member on 16 March 2005. The country participates in the ESA's telecommunication and technology activities and the <a href="/wiki/Global_Monitoring_for_Environment_and_Security" class="mw-redirect" title="Global Monitoring for Environment and Security">Global Monitoring for Environment and Security</a> Initiative. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Centre_of_Scientific_Research_%22Demokritos%22" title="National Centre of Scientific Research &quot;Demokritos&quot;">National Centre of Scientific Research "Demokritos"</a> was founded in 1959. The original objective of the center was the advancement of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear research and technology</a>. Today, its activities cover several fields of science and engineering. </p>
      <p>Greece has one of the highest rates of tertiary enrollment in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[284]</a></sup> while Greeks are well represented in academia worldwide; numerous leading Western universities employ a disproportionately high number of Greek faculty.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[285]</a></sup> Greek scientific publications have grown significantly in terms of <a href="/wiki/Research_impact" class="mw-redirect" title="Research impact">research impact</a>, surpassing both the EU and global average from 2012 to 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[286]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Notable Greek scientists of modern times include <a href="/wiki/Georgios_Papanikolaou" title="Georgios Papanikolaou">Georgios Papanikolaou</a> (inventor of the <a href="/wiki/Pap_test" title="Pap test">Pap test</a>), mathematician <a href="/wiki/Constantin_Carath%C3%A9odory" title="Constantin Carathéodory">Constantin Carathéodory</a> (known for the <a href="/wiki/Carath%C3%A9odory_theorem_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Carathéodory theorem (disambiguation)">Carathéodory theorems</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carath%C3%A9odory_conjecture" title="Carathéodory conjecture">Carathéodory conjecture</a>), astronomer <a href="/wiki/E._M._Antoniadi" title="E. M. Antoniadi">E. M. Antoniadi</a>, archaeologists <a href="/wiki/Ioannis_Svoronos" title="Ioannis Svoronos">Ioannis Svoronos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valerios_Stais" title="Valerios Stais">Valerios Stais</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spyridon_Marinatos" title="Spyridon Marinatos">Spyridon Marinatos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manolis_Andronikos" title="Manolis Andronikos">Manolis Andronikos</a> (discovered the tomb of <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_Macedon" title="Philip II of Macedon">Philip II of Macedon</a> in <a href="/wiki/Vergina" title="Vergina">Vergina</a>), Indologist <a href="/wiki/Dimitrios_Galanos" title="Dimitrios Galanos">Dimitrios Galanos</a>, botanist <a href="/wiki/Theodoros_G._Orphanides" title="Theodoros G. Orphanides">Theodoros G. Orphanides</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Michael_Dertouzos" title="Michael Dertouzos">Michael Dertouzos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Negroponte" title="Nicholas Negroponte">Nicholas Negroponte</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Argyris" title="John Argyris">John Argyris</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Iliopoulos" title="John Iliopoulos">John Iliopoulos</a> (2007 <a href="/wiki/Dirac_Prize" class="mw-redirect" title="Dirac Prize">Dirac Prize</a> for his contributions on the physics of the charm quark, a major contribution to the birth of the Standard Model, the modern theory of Elementary Particles), <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Sifakis" title="Joseph Sifakis">Joseph Sifakis</a> (2007 <a href="/wiki/Turing_Award" title="Turing Award">Turing Award</a>, the "Nobel Prize" of Computer Science), <a href="/wiki/Christos_Papadimitriou" title="Christos Papadimitriou">Christos Papadimitriou</a> (2002 <a href="/wiki/Knuth_Prize" title="Knuth Prize">Knuth Prize</a>, 2012 <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6del_Prize" title="Gödel Prize">Gödel Prize</a>), <a href="/wiki/Mihalis_Yannakakis" title="Mihalis Yannakakis">Mihalis Yannakakis</a> (2005 <a href="/wiki/Knuth_Prize" title="Knuth Prize">Knuth Prize</a>) and physicist <a href="/wiki/Dimitri_Nanopoulos" title="Dimitri Nanopoulos">Dimitri Nanopoulos</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Greece" title="Demographics of Greece">Demographics of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Brainsik-ermoupoli.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Brainsik-ermoupoli.jpg/400px-Brainsik-ermoupoli.jpg" decoding="async" width="400" height="177" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Brainsik-ermoupoli.jpg/600px-Brainsik-ermoupoli.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Brainsik-ermoupoli.jpg/800px-Brainsik-ermoupoli.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3060" data-file-height="1357"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Brainsik-ermoupoli.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Hermoupolis" class="mw-redirect" title="Hermoupolis">Hermoupolis</a>, on the island of <a href="/wiki/Syros" title="Syros">Syros</a>, is the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Cyclades" title="Cyclades">Cyclades</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the official statistical body of Greece, the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Statistical_Authority" title="Hellenic Statistical Authority">Hellenic Statistical Authority</a> (ELSTAT), the country's total population in 2011 was 10,816,286.<sup id="cite_ref-ELSTAT_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ELSTAT-8">[7]</a></sup> Eurostat places the current population at 10.7 million in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[287]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Greek society has changed rapidly over the last several decades, coinciding with the <a href="/wiki/Aging_of_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Aging of Europe">wider European trend</a> of declining fertility and rapid aging. The <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a> in 2003 stood at 9.5 per 1,000 inhabitants, significantly lower than the rate of 14.5 per 1,000 in 1981. At the same time, the mortality rate increased slightly from 8.9 per 1,000 inhabitants in 1981 to 9.6 per 1,000 inhabitants in 2003. Estimates from 2016 show the birth rate decreasing further still to 8.5 per 1,000 and mortality climbing to 11.2 per 1,000.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[288]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Greecepop.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Greecepop.svg/250px-Greecepop.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Greecepop.svg/375px-Greecepop.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Greecepop.svg/500px-Greecepop.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Greecepop.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population pyramid of Greece in 2017
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Fertility_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Fertility rate">fertility rate</a> of 1.41 children per woman is well below the <a href="/wiki/Replacement_fertility_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Replacement fertility rate">replacement rate of 2.1</a>, and is one of the lowest in the world, considerably below the high of 5.47 children born per woman in 1900.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[289]</a></sup> Subsequently, Greece's median age is 44.2 years, the seventh-highest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[290]</a></sup> In 2001, 16.71 percent of the population were 65 years old and older, 68.12 percent between the ages of 15 and 64 years old, and 15.18 percent were 14 years old and younger.<sup id="cite_ref-nssg_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nssg-298">[291]</a></sup> By 2016, the proportion of the population age 65 and older had risen to 20.68 percent, while the proportion of those aged 14 and younger declined to slightly below 14 percent. </p>
      <p>Marriage rates began declining from almost 71 per 1,000 inhabitants in 1981 until 2002, only to increase slightly in 2003 to 61 per 1,000 and then fall again to 51 in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-nssg_298-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nssg-298">[291]</a></sup> Moreover, divorce rates have seen an increase from 191.2 per 1,000 marriages in 1991 to 239.5 per 1,000 marriages in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-nssg_298-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nssg-298">[291]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As a result of these trends, the average Greek household is smaller and older than in previous generations. The economic crisis has exacerbated this development, with 350,000-450,000 Greeks, predominantly young adults, emigrating since 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[292]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cities">Cities</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Greece" class="mw-redirect" title="List of cities in Greece">List of cities in Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Almost two-thirds of the Greek people live in urban areas. Greece's largest and most influential metropolitan centres are those of <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thessaloniki" title="Thessaloniki">Thessaloniki</a>—that latter commonly referred to as the <i lang="el-Latn" title="Greek-language romanization">symprotévousa</i> (<span lang="el" title="Greek-language text">συμ<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CF%80%CF%81%CF%89%CF%84%CE%B5%CF%8D%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%83%CE%B1" class="extiw" title="wikt:πρωτεύουσα">πρωτεύουσα</a></span>, <abbr title="literal translation">lit.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap"> </span>'co-capital'<sup id="cite_ref-Greek_Experience_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Greek_Experience-300">[293]</a></sup>)—with metropolitan populations of approximately 4 million and 1 million inhabitants respectively. Other prominent cities with urban populations above 100,000 inhabitants include <a href="/wiki/Patras" title="Patras">Patras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heraklion" title="Heraklion">Heraklion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Larissa" title="Larissa">Larissa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volos" title="Volos">Volos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhodes_(city)" title="Rhodes (city)">Rhodes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ioannina" title="Ioannina">Ioannina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agrinio" title="Agrinio">Agrinio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chania" title="Chania">Chania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chalcis" title="Chalcis">Chalcis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cities_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cities-301">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The table below lists the largest cities in Greece, by population contained in their respective contiguous built up urban areas, which are either made up of many municipalities, evident in the cases of Athens and Thessaloniki, or are contained within a larger single municipality, case evident in most of the smaller cities of the country. The results come from the preliminary figures of the population census that took place in Greece in May 2011. </p>
      <p><br> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">10</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Serres" title="Serres">Serres</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Central_Macedonia" title="Central Macedonia">Central Macedonia</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">58,287</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">20</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Agrinio" title="Agrinio">Agrinio</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Western_Greece" title="Western Greece">Western Greece</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">46,899 </td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><br> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Greece" title="Religion in Greece">Religion in Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">Greek Orthodox Church</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Greece" title="Church of Greece">Church of Greece</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Muslim_minority_of_Greece" title="Muslim minority of Greece">Muslim minority of Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hellenismos" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenismos">Hellenismos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_religion" title="Ancient Greek religion">Ancient Greek religion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Romaniote_Jews" title="Romaniote Jews">Romaniote Jews</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px"> 
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black"> 
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:Yellow"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 1589.4544843865px; border-left-color:Green"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Green"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Green"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 524.21835811132px; border-left-color:Honeydew"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Honeydew"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Honeydew"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 212.51081731572px; border-left-color:DeepSkyBlue"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DeepSkyBlue"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:DeepSkyBlue"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 137.63819204712px; border-left-color:Orchid"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Orchid"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Orchid"></div> 
        </div> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <p>Religiosity in Greece (2017)<sup id="cite_ref-Pew2017_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pew2017-4">[3]</a></sup> </p> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Orchid; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodoxy">Eastern Orthodoxy</a> (90%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:DeepSkyBlue; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Other <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> (exc.<a href="/wiki/Catholics" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholics">Catholics</a>) (3%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Honeydew; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">Irreligion</a> (4%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Green; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> (2%)
         </div>
